Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
1. Staff: He currently works with a research person, docketing clerk, patent and trademark docketing clerk, paralegals, legal secretary, billing and finance professionals, and marketing team. Billing and accounting and marketing we can handle, but we're not in good shape for his practice wrt to the other categories. We'd need a paralegal and secretary on the East Coast - I don't see our staff out in SF having bandwidth or capabilities to take on a practice of this size. So not only would that be a bottleneck, we'd also have to find staff that can handle docketing both on litigation and in USPTO hearings, because we can't support full-time docketing clerks. Frankly, I'm not sure whether that exists. In any event, if he's serious, we'd need to put all hands on decks right away to try. 

2. Lawyers - he needs a variety of lawyers to support his practice, in different sciences. So even though he can only support one, maybe two lwyers, he needs a variety to be able to do the work he needs. He knows of a few people that could join the network and help out. If those work out, he would probably need one full-time of counsel type, but also "junior associate support" from time to time. At the very least, we'd need to find an excellent IP litigator full time (not just John Hintz, it seems), also before he joins. 

A bit of good news is that he is piqued by the idea of working from home. The bad news is that we'd need at least a small office in NYC regardless because of the recent cases that came down from the NY court of appeals.

Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
From recruiter in initial intro: 

Stephen’s financial situation is such that he feels he needs some sort of minimal base salary to deal with some expenses and to do some marketing travel to Croatia and some other places to reconnect with all of his contacts and sources. Drinker Biddle is discussing giving him some sort of draw or base salary that would be the equivalent of what they pay a 5th or 6th year associate.
 
Based upon what I told Stephen about Rimon he realizes that your firm model is probably not really set up to pay base salaries, draws and guaranteed compensation, so he wonders if the following might be a way of addressing this issue in a manner that would not offend “the system” at Rimon. He would like to know if, assuming he joined Rimon, would Rimon consider providing him a “a one-time advance” that he would be obligated to repay out of his first receipts or by the end of a specific period of time. He is hoping that Rimon might consider thinking of it as some kind of signing compensation, rather than some deviation from the presumed Rimon policy that you probably don’t generally do draws.  Stephen hopes that by requiring Stephen to repay the advance, that this would further be in sync with your firm’s policy or structure.

 I think he is inclined to accept an offer from Rimon. He seems motivated and he really likes the business model, the law firm attitude, and the people.
 
From recruiter after meeting with Trachtenberg and Monsanto:

I see only two items that could pose potential obstacles.
 
1.      I don’t have any idea what other offer(s) he might get from some other firm such as Drinker Biddle. I think he would prefer Rimon over any other firm, all things being equal. However, another firm might make an offer that is too attractive economically in terms of guaranteed compensation which could render both offers unequal and tip the balance to the other firm; and
 

2.      Related to the first item, as I mentioned in my original profile of Stephen, he needs some sort of cash advance, if not a modest base salary. I don’t know if Stephen has any precise number in mind. For your convenience and to refresh your memory, here is what I wrote on this subject in my introduction of Stephen’s candidacy:

 
“Stephen’s candidacy at Rimon would otherwise seem like a no-brainer, but here is the ‘fly in the ointment.’ Stephen’s financial situation is such that he feels he needs some sort of minimal base salary to deal with some expenses and to do some marketing travel to Croatia and some other places to reconnect with all of his contacts and sources. [Drinker Biddle] is discussing giving him some sort of draw or base salary that would be the equivalent of what they pay a 5th or 6th year associate.
 
Based upon what I told Stephen about Rimon he realizes that your firm model is probably not really set up to pay base salaries, draws and guaranteed compensation, so he wonders if the following might be a way of addressing this issue in a manner that would not offend ‘the system’ at Rimon. He would like to know if, assuming he joined Rimon, would Rimon consider providing him a ‘a one-time advance’ that he would be obligated to repay out of his first receipts or by the end of a specific period of time. He is hoping that Rimon might consider thinking of it as some kind of signing compensation, rather than some deviation from the presumed Rimon policy that you probably don’t generally do draws.  Stephen hopes that by requiring Stephen to repay the advance, that this would further be in sync with your firm’s policy or structure.”
 
It is my understanding  that there has not been any discussion on this issue to date, so obviously you would have to come to some resolution before Stephen would be in a position to accept an offer.

Call with YPS - He's in the middle of a divorce settlement, so cashflow is a problem right now - 25,000/30,000 advance requested. Told him it won't be a problem.

MATT POPPE, NOTES FROM LUNCH MEET:
I wouldn't oppose an offer if others felt strongly, but he didn't fill me with enthusiasm.  He didn't give me the sense that he has either a strong active docket or much chance of cross-selling. He doesn't have IPR experience, so I wouldn't be able to collaborate with him on patent litigation.  His ideas about a patent prosecution referral service seemed interesting, but I think our leadership's energy is better spent on other forms of law firm innovation.  Finally, Jonathan didn't impress me from a personality standpoint the way others at Rimon have.  With that said, Jim's input is probably more important than mine as I would expect him to have more opportunities to refer work to a patent prosecutor than I do.

Title: Partner
Private Management Notes:
YPS Call - very difficult for me to evaluate the situation because (a) his English is far from perfect, so there was a fair bit of confusion around deeper questions and (b) I don't know his area. But that said, it seems doubtful he fits the bill of a Rimon partner based on experience alone. His first job in the US, at Bay Area IP Group (oddly based in Reno) was for the stated reason of "just finding somewhere to do his OPT" (post school visa work). So his experience there wasn't very material. Then he went to ANBO for 8 months, left there, went to another firm in China for 7 months where he was a partner (although I'm not sure what that means, give he was pretty junior), but left it because he didn't like the firm and went back to the first firm. He now practices under the practice of an immigration attorney, Shen, in association with ANBO, although "not really part of the firm". So he doesn't have any history of working in a sophisticated platform for any extended period of time. Closest that comes to this is Baker, but that was very junior for two years.

He also certainly can't draft agreements in English, so the question is whether he'd just be practicing Chinese law?

REGARDING BILLINGS 2015vs2016: In each of the last 2 years a significant amount of my billings came from one time, non-recurring events.  

In 2015, a client I originated, FieldOne. was sold to Microsoft.   We represented the company in the sale, which was a significant part of my billings for the year.  In 2016, there was some post-closing work, but that is mostly done.    The former CEO of FieldOne recently has become the CEO of another area company and I do anticipate receiving work from them in 2017, but initially not at that magnitude.

Similarly, in 2016 a client I originated, Gerald Minkowitz, was sued and the litigation has generated a large amount of fees.  Although I believe I will have a role in the case until it settles/goes to trial, I do not believe the work will transition from McCarter (too much institutional knowledge of the case to transition).  Dr. Minkowitz is now working on other investments, so I believe that the work will continue, but again, not at the same magnitude.

I prefer to under-promise, over-deliver and my estimate reflects that.  To be clear, it does not reflect any desire on my part to dial back my practice.  On the contrary, I believe the Rimon platform will allow me to grow my practice.  One of the major appeals of Rimon to me is the billing flexibility to pitch to clients to be a "Fractional-GC"  on a flat-fee basis. Given my background, I believe that is my sweet-spot, but it is not cost effective at $495 an hour.  In addition, I believe that at Rimon I will have the flexibility to make multiple trips to Israel and make a serious business development drive.  I am already targeting trips in February and May that will center on major venture industry events, but include many other meetings.

From Frederick: This is a BIG Picture thinker and his opinion of (old school) law firm management is very low.

He talked about the need for associates but if we can evidence specific lawyers who could staff his case, as well as discuss our desire to grow a national and international practice, he’ll be excited about that. Even though he has a solid client base, his belief is that internal referrals are paramount to a successful comm lit practice, because of the ebbs and flows of settlements etc…
He’s very outgoing and talkative so let him do most of it. He uses analogies very effectively e.g. he brought up that he crewed at Yale and coached the boats at U. Va., and that oftentimes, law firm management is like having someone on board who is either not rowing or rowing in the opposite direction. 
He really does have tremendous business acumen so management by “Coloring Books & Crayons” as he puts it, drives him crazy. The boutique he’s considering will have the same mindset so acknowledge how highly I feel about his business mind, and how valuable he could be in helping us recruit and vet potential candidates – something he is VERY interested in doing for us.
If he believes we can provide the support needed, that internal marketing will eventually bear fruit (I promised $0.00 but said the formula speaks for itself, as do the numbers), and are truly set on growing a national litigation practice, he’ll join.

Tell us a little about your clients:
My practice has focused on assisting clients investing in Kazakhstan.  The clients consist of the major publicly-traded oil & gas companies and their Kazakhstan joint ventures.  These have included Chevron, ExxonMobil, China National Petroleum Corporation, Total, Shell, Eni, Inpex and others.  I also act for engineering and oil services firms, such as Fluor Corporation, Halliburton, Parker Drilling, and others.  During the past year, I have also begun to consult to renewable energy investors that are clients of other Dechert partners, which are considering major solar and wind projects in Kazakhstan.
I have attached an Excel sheet that provides annual revenues from clients of the Almaty office of which I have been managing partner since 2005 (first at Chadbourne & Parke, and then at Dechert).    
I can provide a breakdown of the fees paid by specific clients each year during the past several years.  However, I should emphasize that my interest in Rimon is predicated on pursuing a different approach for my practice.  My practice has always focused on having an office in Kazakhstan and a team of Kazakhstani lawyers.  This has required that I live in Kazakhstan or constantly commute to Kazakhstan to administer the office.  The product that we offer is one in which the clients rely upon our having a Kazakhstan legal team on the ground.  This has been successful when I have lived in Kazakhstan; it has faced challenges when I have lived in Washington, DC and commuted to Almaty.
I am now considering disengaging from the model of relying on a Kazakhstan office, in order to build an international energy and infrastructure practice.  I would, of course, need to start with matters pertaining to Kazakhstan, where I have experience and connections.  Initially, I could only expect my clients to use me for a narrow segment of the services I have historically provided to them.  That is, I could negotiate renewable energy deals, advocate on.. (see attachment for more)..

Private Management Notes: Reference check with Ed was good, but not perfect. He did say the he liked her a lot, that she was easy to get along with, left on great terms etc, The overall general feel was certainly positive, not negative. But he seemed to hesitate on a number of points. For instance, when asked about her technical skills, he said he had to admit that "she was a partner, so he didn't really supervise her work, but that he certainly never heard anything bad or adverse." I probed and asked if they had any mutual clients, where he might have seen her work, but he said he didn't recall. He perhaps mentioned how the "diversity" aspects of bringing in were important a few too many times. I asked how she fit in to a law firm setting - getting along with partners, relating to staff, and he equivocated a bit, saying that transitioning from government to private practice is hard, so there were naturally some transition bumps, etc. but that it worked out fine. Feeling the need to probe a little more, I asked if, money aside, if he could bring her to his present firm, would he? The answer was that he would strongly consider it, etc, but not a definite yes. He said something about how just because you have a lot of contacts, doesn't mean that turning those into clients is easy. Pressing the question another way, I asked if she had a $2M book, would the decision be easy to bring her in. And he finally said, yes, I think that would be easy. So maybe, in the end of the day, he was equivocating because she couldn't bring in work, and that's all. But all worth noting.

Title: Partner
Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
From Lisa Burns after second meeting with Patricia:

I met with Patricia, again, and her colleague, Eric Karlberg, yesterday afternoon for about an hour.  I really think they are interested, but these seem to be the lingering questions:
(1)    The hurdle of transition, especially with almost 5000 clients. Now, I don’t know if all of these clients are still actual clients.  I suspect that these are all people she has dealt with over the last 30 years, but the vast majority of them are probably not active clients, and could have even moved on to another attorney, and she doesn’t even know (having now transitioned to new firms twice in the last 10 years, I have found this to be the case, of course to a much smaller degree.  However, to the extent that she even has half of this clientele, and they come with her, it will be a monumental task for any client service rep and any admin here in Boston.  We need to be able to reassure her that we will provide the resources necessary to make this leap.  By the way, Bill Long, from Chicago, had similar concerns, so if we can bridge this gap for Patricia, we may well be able to bridge it for him too.  This goes for file storage (too vast to turn digital – probably can only do going forward for client matters), as well as original estate planning documents.  For example, I currently fill 1 full fire proof filing cabinet to the brim and we’ve just gotten a second because not another sheet of paper could fit in the first.  It sounds like Patricia has 4-5 of these cabinets currently!  They cost approximately $2-3k/cabinet and they are heavy so they have to be spread out in a floor plan.  So as you can see, these logistics are very real and very much a concern for someone like Patricia (and Bill Long to a lesser extent).  Hiring some dedicated temps to focus just on transition may be the answer. (more in Private Management Notes)
Private Management Notes:
(continued from Private Frederick/Mgmt notes from Lisa Burns):

(2)    Will the model work for her kind of leveraging work down to Eric and to an associate, and to a lesser extent, a paralegal?  I think it should, but it also depends on how she structures things, especially with Eric.  Currently he is of counsel, and works on a contractual basis where he gets a percentage of the dollars collected on the work he performs (I think).  They didn’t give me a ton of details.  I told them that there are many ways to set this up.  Just as we had discussed in our very first telephone call, different groups do things differently. I tried to give her examples, but I think that you are in the best position to run through this with her.  Clearly Scott and I run our practices very similarly with respect to our employees.  However, I know that Frank does something else with respect to his son and Jennifer Dassari.   You have much more information on what combinations might work financially, so it may make sense for you or Yaacov to run through the numbers with her using various methods to see what could possibly work best.  I have sent her and Eric an excel spreadsheet that my husband put together when Deb and I were considering this move.  It is fairly simple in that you estimate what hours you might collect for any given person in your group and at what rate, and then you can figure out other’s costs to figure out your own bottom line results. There were also different cost sharing calculations at different percentages that can be factored in, if for example, she and I were to share costs on an associate and/or a paralegal, etc.   I’ve attached this spreadsheet so you will know what she’s talking about if she mentions it.

Since then, he has been client cycling, working more in Houston and upping his rate to between $3 - $450 an hour – which makes him at least viable for our platform. He generates between $7 - $800 a year. His base comp is $200K and he gets 25% of originations for anything over $500K. His clients are 100% his as they came with him from his solo practice. Because of that and the contrast with Regional Law, this guy REALLY gets it! Additionally, he might help us with the dozens of Houston attorneys who are waiting for someone else to open before they’re go active. 
He just went to Chamberlain Hrdlicka in May and was concerned on two fronts i.e. that it might make him look flaky to clients and that you wouldn’t be open to considering him. I told him I’ve been down this road before. On the client side, it actually looks better to move a few months later, than a year or so later. You say almost nothing by way of explanation and let them make their own assumptions. This is surprisingly effective in evoking empathy because everyone has made a mistake at least once in their career. 
You are a different matter. How will we handle you?

Private Management Notes:
Follow-up notes from Buz 5/19/17: I would recommend a frank  conversation between Michael and Shang Dai, which Michael should initiate. But not to pursue an affiliation of the firms.  
Possiby: what Bari Zahn was describing to me recently as Shang’s understanding, was a misunderstanding of the Rimon structure, economic and compensation model. A better grasp of how we work and can work could well help both parties evaluate the opportunity more constructively.

Although the compensation model of the two firms is similar, the values and objectives of the two firms may not be aligned.  The lawyers in Dai Associates are not uniformly first tier, and if we did find a way to affiliate, I would personally be advocating that more than a few of the Dai Associates lawyers be excused from the table prior to the transaction.  Shang Dai himself is a strong personality and has his own agenda, and it is not centered entirely on his law firm.
According to implications from Bari, Shang’s management style may be more authoritarian, less sensitive, and not entirely consistent with the evolved staff and professional management practiced at Rimon.  The China connection is exciting, and could provide work for other Rimon Lawyers; but Chinese clients present significant fee payment risk issues that are well known in our profession.  And after months of interviewing them very directly, I have concluded that our own Rimon China practice lawyers do not even believe that they need each other, let alone that they would profit from a relationship with Chinese practice lawyers whom they do not know.

ADDED NOTES FROM LISA-MARIE 9/4/17:
His alternative was going solo, so I think having some of the support of  tax, employment, securities, etc. at Rimon would be valuable to him.   But I think he will have to market his straight O&G expertise outside of Rimon. While he writes and speaks, etc. he has not picked up clients through those avenues.  I did not get the sense that he really has fire in his bely to get out there and market and I let him know that his marketing efforts would be on his dime.  Even without really knowing a whole lot about the O&G sector, I didn’t think he had a strong plan as to how he would expand his practice.  I know more about the petrochemical and alternative energy sectors and marketing isn’t always easy.  Much of the information I was able to obtain was through direct questions.  I think we should continue talking with him through other attorneys to get a better sense as to whether he would be a good fit.  I am a bit on the fence.  Given the agonizingly slow pace of my DFI deals this past year as sometimes happens with a DFI finance practice, I need to do a ton of marketing starting now and get out there.  Fortunately, I had the resources to ride it out.  He understands that even with an established practice you really have to be aggressive.  He did not strike super aggressive but I could be wrong.  We need to dig deeper on that by other attorneys speaking with him and his business plan.

INITIAL THOUGHTS FROM BUZ 07/24/17:
If he really has ten companies that give him work, his experience both transactionally and in litigation could be a sustainable and lucrative fit.  He is admitted in a lot of places, which our litigators might like. And he has prosecutorial as well as defense experience.  On energy, he would be taken seriously in oil and gas where I would not. His clientele and references would be my principal focus, but it sounds like an easy transition..  Otherwise he looks like me (only younger and with better teeth) when I was thinking about going solo for the same reasons, the same disappointments, and then I found Rimon. Title: Managing Member and Founder
Private Management Notes:
From recruit's initial email:
"I am looking for a law-firm platform to support my pursuit of this $400mm to $500mm class action, over the next two to four years, in exchange for part of the potential attorneys’ fee award (which might run between $80mm and $120mm).  Litigation finance firms are generally not interested in tax cases, which they view as a complex specialty.  Accordingly, I am looking for a law firm that essentially is willing to “make a bet” on the case, which involves so much money that the risk/reward calculation for a law firm might be very intriguing.
 
As to that calculation, the case I recently filed is unusual because the expenses, aside from my salary, are virtually zero.  There will be no discovery nor expert witness testimony needed -- I know this because I have litigated similar individual cases against DOJ.  The class-notification expenses for this class of 285 teaching hospitals are negligible; the IRS already in its records the identifies of the 285 corporate, nonprofit taxpayers involved.  I can’t imagine that a class won’t be certified:  the IRS chose the wrong interest rate for refunds paid to these taxpayers, which participated in a global concession announced in 2010.  Essentially, the IRS intentionally clicked the wrong button on its interest-computation program.  I am the only attorney in the nation who has handled this type of suit, I invented the argument for recovery, and I am very experienced with suits against the IRS, both in the federal trial courts and in the federal courts of appeals.  I see no realistic possibility that I won’t be appointed class counsel."

Title: Founder, President
Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
MBM asked why book has declined in last three years. Here is his answer:

"... it is one of the primary reasons I am interested in moving to a platform like Rimon.
 
            At our peak, we were four full-time attorneys and a paralegal.  When the economy last crashed, and companies at our end of the market were unable to obtain credit or equity financing, the transactions which are our bread and butter dwindled down to practically none, and we were required to downsize.  Today, we are two attorneys and a paralegal, so we have lost half of the billing power that we once had.  In addition, the downsize caused me to have to devote much more time to client work, which has significantly curtailed the amount of business development I have been able to do.  We also experienced some failed transactions in 2016, which affected our receivables.  We are picking some of it back up through collections efforts, but it had an impact.
 
            In 2015, we did pick up a huge transaction for the firm, which was the sale of Triple H Food Processors to a private equity fund, and that generated a lot of revenue for the Firm.  In 2016 and 2017, we did not have any single transactions that were as large, and so revenue dipped.  Also, we had anticipated a wave of M&A activity from Chinese clients, but the currency restrictions imposed by China in the last half of the year caused that not to materialize.
 
            For 2018, we currently have several good transactions in the pipeline which should make Q1-Q2 more profitable for us than these periods in prior years.  These include a reverse merger for one of our technology clients into a public company (following which we will also handle the public reporting), and two private placements of equity for clients that are in positive revenue.  The SEC work can be very lucrative and is ongoing quarterly and annual reporting.  We view the increase in the level of public company transactions as a good sign for our business as well.
 
            My interest in Rimon, then, is to allow me personally to utilize other attorneys more to handle the work that I bring in, and allow me to focus more on doing business development.  I also feel that being part of the organization will allow me to work with larger and more stable clients, as opposed to the typically very small or pre-revenue startup clients that we have drawn from historically, which will have an impact on both the amount of work we handle and the collectability of the A/Rs it produces.

Title: Partner
Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes: Mark asked an interesting question: given our system, would it be possible for a different partner to call Carolyn and offer her 2X her internal rate to work for that partner rather than Mark.  Not the first time I have heard such a question from a big firm lawyer who might be skeptical that the Rimon model would work at scale. I said if that happened without the other partner asking Mark first, I want to know who that person is, and I want them out of the firm, because that would be entirely counter-cultural.  He seemed satisfied with that answer.  I told him a few stories I knew of times when partners could have gamed the system but refused to do so, out of respect for what we have all signed up for, and how we stress to incoming lawyers that this is a market, but not a flea market.

More notes on Client Billing, per recruit, 9/28/18:
My portables estimate includes both client and matter originations that I am confident will remain with me. 

The firm’s “billing attorney” label is a bit misleading. It identifies who has responsibility for sending bills. I’m billing attorney for other partners’ originated clients, usually because I manage work distribution or have increased the client relationship. I’ve also brought in new clients and have someone else handle billing, because I’m not doing any of the work (e.g., new business succession client, new start-ups needing early corporate support) and don’t want the administrative duty.  

Niagara number is accurate. Patent litigation in EDVa, hotly contested, but likely settling. This is another client that I did not originate, as they were an existing land use/leasing client, but I brought in the litigation. Niagara has explicitly stated that they hired me for the litigation, and want to continue working with me for other IP projects. 

New client collections, not including matter originations, such as the licensing work I brought in from an existing immigration client, or the patent work I brought in from a corporate client:
•	2016 - $75,753
•	2017 - $157,782
•	2018 (through Aug) - $138,344
These numbers are limited to collections from new clients for which the system identifies me as client originating attorney. This does not include jointly-originated clients or new patent litigation matters for which I share origination credit - two categories I consider important in assessing portable business. The Niagara matter is a good example. The client originating and billing attorney helped them secure a land lease a few years back. I saw they were listed as a patent infringement defendant, and pursued/won the representation. They consider themselves my client. Similar situation for large patent portfolio and licensing matters.

Private Management Notes:
Patrick answers: 1/14/19
For reference and confirmation that Rimon complies (or can comply)

For Liability Insurance, Outside counsel shall, at its own expense, obtain and maintain in full force and effect with sound and reputable insurers with AM Best Rating of A-X or better during the term of their engagement, the insurance coverage in sufficient amounts for Workers Compensation, Broad Form Commercial General Liability, Employer’s Liability, and Professional Liability.

Conflict:  Absent unusual circumstances, Morgan Stanley will not normally view outside counsel’s representation of a party involved in a negotiated transaction in which Morgan Stanley is also involved as a conflict that requires a waiver, assuming the other party agrees not to use the law firm if a dispute involving Morgan Stanley arises, and agrees not to object to the law firm’s continued ability to represent Morgan Stanley on other pending and future matters.

Business Continuity Planning
Outside counsel is required to maintain adequate business continuity, disaster recovery, and backup plans in order to perform its obligations hereunder with minimal disruption or delay.

For accounting, Morgan uses Tymetrix 360  (https://www.tymetrix360.com/)

Recruiter comments/advice:
This is a man who generates $5M and not only is he not appreciated, he’s lectured. 
I would suggest that at some point during a call, you ask about his perspective on the client development process. Then I would render a genuine compliment (and at $5M a year, it WOULD be genuine!) and then ask whether if he ended up joining Rimon, he might be willing to share his expertise with others in the firm either locally, via video or whatever. Shelton’s Axiom: Everyone feels taken for granted at some point but no one ever has the problem of feeling too appreciated. This would establish Rimon Management as the contrast to patronizing and dismissive management. 
I might also suggest a preemptive strike along the lines of “If you join Rimon, how would you feel about helping Frederick recruit, vet and build the practice?”

•	No bank in the U.S. would open accounts for U.S. businesses that have Russian parents  
•	Extraordinarily difficult to receive payments from Russian businesses through the American banking system
•	Clients not getting paid for an extended period on products or services that were sold into Russia, concluding that it would be difficult to get paid in a timely manner for work done in the U.S. for Russian clients. 
Not sure that observations are accurate - or conclusive - but provides a reason for being thoughtful before we proceeding with a Russian partner candidate, working for a U.S. law firm, who wants to relocate to the U. S.

Private Management Notes:
Regarding two law suits disclosed in LPQ:

1.  Case 16-O-17825.  Our firm was retained by a client to perform regulatory due diligence on a potential dispensary purchase in LA.  At the time there were no cannabis licenses in LA, just an affirmative defense from prosecution if the dispensary could meet LA's complicated municipal code requirements.  At that point, our belief was that dispensaries that could prove they met the municipal code requirements would be grandfathered and would be eligible for licenses if/when LA ultimately issued licenses (in 2018, this belief ended up being confirmed as accurate).  

Other attorneys at my office performed the due diligence review of documents and cross-checked them against the LA Municipal Code, based on that review they determined that the target dispensary was non-compliant and thus likely would not be ultimately eligible for a license.  

Separate from the due diligence review, Luke Stanton recalled the dispensary name and reviewed another client's file where he believed he had seen the name.  In his review of that other file, he noticed that one of the firm's other clients had (with a different firm representing him) previously purchased that dispensary and then sold it to a different third party (i.e., not the seller in this transaction), creating a chain of title issue on top of the non-compliance concern.

Mr. Stanton was mindful of the duty of confidentiality owed to the other client and asked that client if he could share this information to the potential buyer client to prevent him from buying a dispensary that might not be owned by the seller.  The other client told Mr. Stanton that he could tell the potential buyer client about the existence of the documents, but he was not authorized to share the purchase documents. 

Mr. Stanton provided the due diligence memorandum to the potential purchaser client and also told the potential purchaser client about the chain of title issue.  The potential purchaser c

Title: Partner
Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
More feedback from Justin 2/25/20:
"His mention of his government affairs practice and his separate real estate development, makes me think I might know where a lot of the reputational issue is coming from.   My guess , all conjecture, is that: (1) he is likely buying properties in low income areas; (2) utilizing his political connections to get local jurisdictions to make sure the “green zone” area where cannabis businesses are allowed is small and his property is within the green zone; (3) developing the property and getting it entitled; and then (4) leasing or selling the property to cannabis operators for a large mark-up. I am guessing he is not selling/leasing to his own clients (which would seem like a clear ethical violation), but, instead is doing this to non-clients.  The cannabis industry is a small industry, and this sort of behavior practice makes people in the industry upset that he using his understanding of the law and political connections to profit off of the operators.  
 
He also mentioned he helped cities write their cannabis ordinance.  That also could make certain operators feel like he was sabotaging their opportunity, whether or not accurate.  In terms of conflicts, yes, seeing his LPQ would be helpful.  His city work is part of my concern.  If my client is seeking a license from a city, that could disqualify us from helping.
 
In terms of his and his team’s abilities as attorneys, I am not sure we will be able to determine that from a call.  The subpar work product that my team saw was from several years ago.  And he did mention he has hired a team of experienced attorney.    I feel that other partners not involved in the cannabis space might be a good smell check to see what they think."
Private Management Notes:
We will definitely want to look closely at references here. He joined another firm as a partner for only 8 months while keeping his own firm. He was never at a big firm - just did contract work before his own firm. Billing rates of 275-550/hr.

From Justin: Re: David's mixed reputation:
"...a lot of the early cannabis attorneys came from crim law sphere, and as their clients started cannabis businesses these types of attorneys became cannabis “business attorneys” overnight.  The crim law skillset is generally different from transactional/business law skillset, so in general, these old school cannabis attorneys weren’t that great.  I was telling you this, in the context of how my/Lukian’s practice differentiated ourselves and were able to get a decent market share pretty quickly.
 
Admittedly hearsay, David is one of those guys.  David is a known figure in LA cannabis law.  A few of my clients were formerly his clients and they said he was overpriced and slow.  Some documents his office prepared that were in our client’s files were pretty sloppy.  One client told me that David “stole my opportunity”.  
 
I do not know how much of this is true, if any, but, I do know that people in this space in LA know who David Welch is.
 
On the positive side, he does represent a good amount of capitalized cannabis groups (and some notable non-cannabis groups).  He has a reputation for being a trail blazer in the space."

* He wants to get paid 1099 not W2 (to write off his costs)

I generally agree with David’s comments.  There was a strange dynamic between Peter and Ed.  Peter seemed much more interested in Rimon, however he was very reserved about his interest.  I agree that he may have been holding back due to the possibility of joining Ed.

My gut tells me that Rimon might benefit from Peter and not Ed.

Private Management Notes:
First-glance-observations from Zheng, 3/4/20: 
"His resume looks great.  Good undergrad, good law school, good technical background and good current firm.   Bad luck, too.  He joined two firms that went under.   
We also need more litigators on the east coast.  So definitely worth exploring more.
 
A few things for you to consider:
 
Is he litigating himself or he bringing clients/matters and relying on others?  A certain level of reliance is inevitable. For example, I won’t go in front of the jury in a conservative region of US.  But if he needs a lot of help, we don’t have enough litigators sitting there waiting for work. It means he should bring people with him, or we need to hire more litigators, especially on the east coast, to work with him.  
 
A number of Chinese IP litigators have really only done the technical side of IP litigation, basically they are patent/tech geeks.  They never argued motions, have taken very few depositions and never did anything in court.  They also often have never been involved in anything other than patent litigation.  That can be very good when there is a need for them.  But if you don’t want them, not so good."

Title: Partner
Closing Reason: Chose to stay at current firm
Private Management Notes:
From Faruk's email 1/30/20, re large size of group:

"We agree with you that the number of workers is too high in comparison to our turnover. There are simple reasons for that:
1.      We are a relatively new player in the market. Clients/contacts did not know our brand before June 2018. Therefore, we wanted to invest in profile raising, marketing material, legal newsletters and update, participation in conference, etc. we have generally two youngsters doing that for us. This strategy pays off because our firm is gaining visibility in Luxembourg and outside. 
 
2.      We wanted to create a practice unit focused on litigation. We have a litigation unit that is not entirely integrated in our firm (they are in a different building). They do business litigation, civil law, migration and a certain amount of pro bono work. The reason why we wanted this unit to be “separate” is to avoid the market perceiving us as a “litigation” firm. When our image will be strong enough as a business law firm and when the litigation unit reaches its performance objective, we will integrate it.
 
3.       The third reason is purely tactical: our clients are typically mid-size fortunes, private equity houses and multinationals (typical deal size ranges between €10 million to €800 million). Size does matter for this type of clients. If we are 4 of us, even if we are boast ourselves to be genuinely good at what we do, clients will not entrust us with sizable instructions for the wrong reasons. They would typically think that a firm of 6 or so lawyers cannot handle big closings where hundreds of millions are at stake.  We therefore need a critical mass merely for a perceptual/psychological reasons. 
 
We believe our model is healthy because it fits our ambitions: organic growth. We have a big potential yet to explore and translate into real profits. That is the reason why we are interested in a bigger network - to accelerate growth and open new doors for us to develop."
Tell us a little about your clients: (See client list in Presentation - attached)
Closing reason details: Growing current firm

Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
David Lavan. It was a bit of an odd reference, in that David seemed very tired, or distracted, or something . . . it wasn’t a very natural feeling conversation. In substance, David said all the right things – that Tim is a great guy, that his clients love him, that he wouldn’t hesitate to have Tim work with his best clients, etc. But on the other hand, I heard him audibly yawn a few times on the call . . . . Reading between the lines, I did get the sense that Tim and the Philadelphia office are getting jettisoned as a cost-saving measure for the firm.
Andrew Maher: I spoke to another of Tim’s references today. It was with an attorney who worked alongside Tim as an associate for 8 years at two different firms. They’re friends. It was a totally positive reference check, EXCEPT when the reference slipped up. He had four kids screaming in the background and it may have caused him to lose focus. Here’s what happened: I asked if he could speak at all to Tim’s honesty and integrity. He began by saying that he thinks Tim is totally trustworthy, never questioned his honesty, and then said something like “ the whole thing with the lawsuit and Fisher Broyles, I really think it was just a slip up, because it had been dismissed, but I don’t think he intended anything, etc.”. I didn’t know what he was talking about, but I realized he slipped up, and wanted to probe a little further. So I asked him if he was referring to the lawsuit by his former clients and he said yes. And I asked what Fisher’s connection to all this was. He paused, because he realized he goofed. He danced around a little, and I didn’t want to press him because I knew he’d feel terrible, but I think I gleaned that he got pretty far along in conversations with Fisher, and failed to disclose the lawsuit against him, and Fisher found out. They either declined to give or pulled an offer on that basis. That’s probably when he wrote us that long email about the lawsuit.

Title: Partner
Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
Business Plan:

Startups: Startups that touch on the sports betting space require corporate counsel who is familiar with the space (and its associated pitfalls) as well as regulatory counsel to guide them through each state in which they seek to do business.  I reasonably expect that I can generate approximately $75k in first-year fees through this channel.

·        Vigit: I am an advisor to this sports betting social platform, which is raising a Series A.  They are using outside counsel that is not as familiar with gaming and quite expensive.  They will need ongoing work involving both their corporate structure and potential gaming regulatory issues.

·        Bet Prophet:  I am informally advising this startup gaming company.  They are live in the UK and will need experienced gaming counsel in the US for regulatory issues.

·        Betcha: I am informally advising this company and previously referred them to outside counsel who was experienced in gaming work, but he recently left his firm.

Gaming: Gaming companies generally have experienced counsel but are often looking for other attorneys who understand the space to do certain types of work at a lower cost.  They are also actively seeking to partner with or acquire smaller companies within this space.  I reasonably expect that I can generate approximately $100k in first-year fees through this channel.

·        Rush Street Gaming: Rivers/SugarHouse is one of their affiliated entities.  They have a need for outside legal work to be done less expensively, most notably for their Rush Street Interactive division, which has a number of licensing and other more routine agreements that need to be redlined.  I am close with the lead of legal/compliance and CEO for Rush Street Gaming, as well as the President and General Counsel for Rush Street Interactive.  They are continuing to expand their online operations across numerous jurisdictions.

·        Penn National:  I know their General Counsel well and their former GC is a good friend.  They are aggressively growing their online platform.

·        Wind Creek:  They recently expanded into PA by acquiring Sands Bethlehem.  I know their PA property GC very well.  They are a tribal entity and their PA acquisition is their first foray into state-regulated gaming.

·        Kambi:  This European sports betting B2B provider recently established a US presence and has told me that they are waiting to bring on US-based inhouse counsel.  I worked closely with this company and know several of their executives. 

Sports:  Teams, leagues, and schools are eager to generate sponsorship dollars associated with sports betting while also worried about various compliance issues.  I reasonably expect that I can generate approximately $50k in first-year fees through this channel. 

·        Eagles:  Their deputy GC (and her husband) are friends, as is their former SVP in charge of corporate partnerships who remains close with several executives there.  They are actively exploring this space and have dipped their toe in the water but are looking to do far more.

·        Flyers:  I sit on a non-profit board with their GC and have negotiated a deal with them before when I was at Rivers.  They are active in this space as well as the esports space and have a casino being built next door to their arena.

·        NCAA:  I have contacts with a number of collegiate conferences that are increasingly worried about compliance issues.

Venture: Venture capital firms that are looking at deals within this space need counsel who is familiar with the regulatory issues surrounding it.  They also serve as a pipeline for introductions to startups.  I reasonably expect that I can generate approximately $75k in first-year fees through this channel. 

·        SeventySix Capital: I am close with the Managing Partner and am likely joining his company’s advisory arm.  They are active in the world of sports tech investing.

·        Red & Blue: I am close with the Managing Partner.  He has told me that he is looking to get involved in tech companies related to sports and sports betting.

·        Osage: One of their principals is a close friend from college.  They are very cost sensitive and I believe there is a great opportunity to become involved with their acquisitions and/or portfolio companies.

·        Stadia:  I know their managing partner and have been asked to judge a prior startup competition. 

Athletes: Similar to sports teams, current athletes are looking at the sponsorship opportunities available within this space, and former athletes are looking at investment opportunities.  I reasonably expect that I can generate approximately $50k in first-year fees through this channel. 

·        SeventySix Capital Athlete Venture Group:  See above re SeventySix.  One of their arms attracts post-athletic career athletes who are looking to become involved in businesses.  They are often in need of trusted advisors.

·        Neustadt Group:  The head of this sports agency has been a friend since childhood.  Several of his clients pursue opportunities after their playing careers are over.

Law firm collaboration: Several law firms with relationships in the sports world are being asked to work on deals that involve betting/gaming issues and lack the expertise to do so.  I reasonably expect that I can generate approximately $50k in first-year fees through this channel. 

·        Morgan Lewis:  They have a robust sports practice but nobody who understands the gaming landscape.  They have told me that they would like to hire me as gaming counsel to help them on deals.

·        Saul Ewing:  They have a burgeoning sports practice as well but do not have experienced gaming attorneys.  They have spoken with me about working together on certain deals.

Other (non sports/gaming): I reasonably expect that I can generate approximately $100k in first-year fees through this channel. 

·        Glenmede Trust:  Their GC is a good friend.  He was previously the GC at Penn National.

·        Post Brothers:  Their GC is a friend who is always looking to reduce his costs.

·        Day & Zimmermann:  My cousin is their in-house counsel who oversees all employment issues.

Title: Partner
Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
He needs two senior associates (or service partners) with good credentials to do the work he generates

From Brian Hafter: (Confidential)
 1.   I don’t see a book of $1.5 million or anything close to it – and I expect that much or a part of his “book” is on contingency fee.  Whether he would have success replicating his alleged book from North Carolina seems suspect.
 
2.  He has been a party to lawsuits/arbitrations with his former firm and with clients.  That’s a red flag for sure.    I am personally friends with Miles Feldman (a name partner at Raines Feldman).  Miles is a stand up guy.   At the right time, I can reach out and find out about this guy, if asked to do so.  
 
3.  He seems to bounce around a lot – and even left the recent firm he started (where he was the lead name partner).  Another red flag.
 
4.   Quite significantly, our litigators appear before JAMS in arbitration and mediations all the time.   I have two mediations before JAMS this week alone, and many pending arbitrations.   For me, his CURRENT lawsuit against JAMS alone would be a deal breaker – because we cannot risk a JAMS arbitrator being biased against Rimon in an unrelated case that the firm is handling.  Fair or not,  I frankly don’t care whether his case against JAMS has merit or not . . . you can’t sue JAMS and expect your partners to regularly practice law before that body.   We run the risk of getting tagged with it.   
 
5.  This concerns me as well:   “I am looking to bill 750 hours per year managing cases.  I need a firm with associates and service partners who can help me monetize my book which enables me to focus on bringing in business.”   The reality is that we don’t have the types of litigation associates he is talking about – i.e., ones that are sitting around waiting to handle cases that he would “manage” – let alone litigation associates outside of California.   We also cannot hand over one of his “very specialized” cases to a (part-time) associate like Laura or Kendra – who lack experience to handle such matters – for him to supervise (from North Carolina).   While we are successful at handling cases remotely, this presents a set of challenges we are not equipped to handle through our current (small) litigation associate pool.   While I am always happy to discuss personally handling litigation that our partners bring in, I also don’t have an interest in handling cases for this particular lawyer (at least based on what I have seen so far) – and I am confident lawyers like Scott Raber and others would view this opportunity similarly.   To be clear, if he is suing JAMS, that alone is enough for me to say “no” – because of how it could impact my other clients in unrelated cases.
 
6.  Ironically, the only thing that did not concern me was the lower case writing . . . odd, but that’s the least of the issues.

Title: Partner
Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
attached please find my numbers for the months of January, February, March, and the first 15 days of April 2020. They are pretty consistent so far; I waited until mid-April to confirm consistency. These numbers are directly from the firm's case management software; they take into account my clients only, 95% of which will come with me. They do not reflect any of my partner's clients, who may also decide to leave (whether entirely or just in part). I'd rather use conservative numbers on my end; if they end up being improved, great for us. 

Some of my cases are on contingency (for example, I have an appeal on contingency where the other side posted a bond) or on a hybrid fee, where there is a premium to a lower hourly rate if I end up winning the case; however, these are the exception. 

As far as the employees that I would like to bring with me, as stated, there are three. 
1. Tereza Horakova, Esq. who lives in NYC and makes $104k per year. She bills at $300 per hour (litigation)
2. Valeria Angelucci, Esq. who lives in South Florida and makes $75k per year. She bills at an equivalent of $250 per hour, but I am working improving that (corporate work). 
3. Yolanda Arencibia, who is the paralegal in charge of the real estate closings, at $50k per year. She bills work for $120k per year. 

My rate is $350/400 per hour.

I told Tereza and Valeria about a potential change of firm, to make sure that they do not have an objection in principle. They do not. I have not yet spoken to Yolanda, because the situation is a bit more delicate. She is best friend with the other paralegal at the firm, who won't be able to join, and thus I want to wait a bit before mentioning the idea of moving firm. 

As I mentioned, and as reflected on the partial numbers, my portfolio this year should be $800k (average of $60k per month), without including any extra work that my partner's clients may decide they want to give me or any work my team and I may be able to do for Rimon's other partners. 

I understand that Rimon has generally a policy whereby the numbers work if there are at least $500k per lawyer in portfolio, due to some fixed costs like legal research, malpractice, insurance, third party software, etc. These fixed costs are billed on a "per lawyer" basis even if they end up not being used by the lawyer. 

Accordingly, I understand that you need to look into whether my numbers work with three lawyers. After our call I went back and looked at the billables - the expectation is that Tereza bills around $350k, Valeria $250k and Yolanda $120k. With those numbers, all I am left to bill is around $100k. How is that? The problem that I have been having at the firm where I am now is that I bill a lot (A LOT) of non-billable for administrative, management, and marketing. This includes touching up the website, the LinkedIn page, fixing the software for the team etc. We have an IT Company, but sometimes it's just better and easier for me to do it directly. Add to that the rainmaking, and I have very little time available to actually bill. Of course, I bill in excess of $100k a year ($250/300k), but the excess goes towards my partner's portfolio. So, if I were to move to Rimon and free up my time, arguably, I would be able to bill more and increase the portfolio. The question is whether I would have the actual work to bill on, as billable hours are not perfectly elastic with available time.

However, I am not comfortable letting go of Valeria and Tereza (or Yolanda, for that matter). They are the backbone of what I built to date. They are super smart, committed, and resolution-oriented. I would prefer to cut my compensation to make up for the lack of a portfolio that is sufficient to cover the fixed "per user" cost. Then, once I am part of Rimon I am confident that I can grow my portfolio - and maybe other partners will realize the great value that the three of them bring to the table and that would be able to offset some (or all) of the "per user" costs.
Closing Reason: Chose to stay at current firm

HE IS WILLING TO MAKE A LITTLE LESS TO MAKE THE NUMBERS WORK FOR US

Bringing two lawyers: salaries $104,000 and $75,000. May need a real estate closer, but depends on Rimon's structure; her salary would be around $50k

Title: Partner
Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
Alan Chen Notes:
I have worked with Jayashree on a few small matters and one large litigation in the past 2 to 3 years. We shared associates and worked with many of the same partners within the IP practice group (prior firm).
 
That said, the descriptions below are not consistent with my understanding of her book. Though she has the core background and competence, she worked with a group of other partners on business development and I am uncertain about how much of her book is truly portable. She was brought in as a service partner and I don’t think that role evolved very much. 
 
Also, she is generally very aggressive in litigation, and her billing reflects that attitude. Because of that, relationship partners need to keep a close eye on her cases to adhere to budget and client expectations. 

That said, I think there is value in talking with her if you expect the IP team needs additional support in the form of service partners. 

Please note my knowledge of her book is slightly outdated, and there is usually room in a large IP team for members with different litigation styles, even if it is very different from my own preferences. The discussion re her aggressiveness was not meant to raise doubt about her credibility relating to competence. The issue is how aggressive litigators can drove up cost of litigation and create a lot of tension within the associate (difficult assignments and workloads) and partnership ranks (budgeting and client management). That’s just based on my observation by working with her from a distance, and on feedback from other partners who worked closely with her. I think these concerns would be alleviated if she is primarily servicing her own clients. That should change the dynamics of her billing practice.
Closing Reason: Chose more traditional firm;Book was not high enough;Needs were too expensive

"I try to make it a practice not to disparage any law firms as I don’t have first hand knowledge about how things work at any particular firm, but by multiple accounts Fox Rothschild sounds like a place where folks have some pretty sharp elbows, more senior partners poach credit for matters that more junior partners bring in.

I was able to dispel some of his misconceptions and he became interested in learning more but he has questions/concerns that I think are born out of his experiences in working in big law. 

In particular, Dan wondered about how the ability to set one’s internal rate, and change it over time, didn’t lead to internal bidding wars and partners trying to jockey and undercut other partners by dropping rates by $25/hour and making themselves more attractive to handle matters."

Title: Partner
Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
Buz's feedback upon presenting: 
I vote yes, but I have materially lower expectations for Jim's economic success at Rimon than he may have for himself, for a few reasons.  

(1) his revenue expectations depend substantially upon his trustee work, which I am not at all convinced will follow him, except possibly for his Japanese financial client (can we test this?) and (1)(a), making the most of his trustee work will in his particular case depend upon hiring and billing out his paralegal, whom Michael may reasonably want him to pay for, and Jim may reasonably not want to take that risk. 

2) His asset finance and leasing work is not one that will throw off anything to the rest of us, even to Q, who can do the same things, but for a different client base.  Jim states that he does throw off litigation, bankruptcy, and tax and I do not contest that, but my guess is that it is not significant, and will be less if all of his trustee work does not come along with him.  Do we know differently? 

(3) Not for nothing, but in my long experience the concept of an "energy efficiency finance practice" is a chimera-ish, if not entirely wishful extrapolation derived from maybe two interesting, clever, and inventive (but by now probably failed and in litigation) deals, and not an industry trend (unless it is a downward trend) or even a niche.  

Nevertheless, if he sticks to it, Jim can probably make a nice living from his business plan at Rimon and in terms of structured asset finance, he and Q would make a solid team presentation that would cover everything finance-able.  But either of them could and would do the largest and most complicated deals in their collective space without help from the other.  Gun to my head, I would predict that Jim will choose another traditional law firm model, or suck it up and stay at McCarter English, for safety, and I would not say that would be a wrong decision.  We would probably not hurt ourselves by saying yes, because he is a serious and well-credentialed transactional attorney with very serious clients in his current firm,  and a clear bias for business development and collaboration, but we would not be hurting him by saying no.
Private Management Notes: His paralegal gets about $90k a year - billed out at $275 per hour
Reference 1 Notes:
1) David Adler (Exec Committee and Partner at McCarter): Worked together on many matters including Deutsche Bank's Tribune indentured trustee case for eight years - $3Bil matter with $8Mil in billings that went through a trial that James brought in. Says James is "best trustee lawyer I have seen." James works well with others in the firm and is highly trusted and liked. David asked James not to leave the firm, but James wants to go somewhere that is more collaborative and flexible.

2) David Doucette (Client, VP @ US Bank)- Jim has represented David for 11 years in all matters. Jim knows corporate trust and municipal work inside out. Work is done efficiently and expertly. Very accessible and quick. Close about 4-5 deals a year together, and plan to continue doing so.

3) James Giaimo (client, VP of Hitachi) - Hitachi has been his client for 20 years and James Giaimo has been working with him for 12 years. Everyone thinks very highly of him and sees him as their go-to lawyer. Excellent lawyer, great in a team, honest, direct, and easy to work with. Highly recommended. They plan to continue giving him same level of work (above $300k a year).
Tell us a little about your clients: Jim also acts as Trustee for his big financials like Wells Fargo, for their deals.  His largest volume client is a US subsidiary of a Japanese financial institution, financing energy efficiency transactions. Clients are in NYC and Southern Connecticut

Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
Unedited notes from YPS 9/17/20:
I am writing my notes here, as I’m never really sure what to place in the public vs private notes but want to convey my thoughts in a somewhat linear way. 

I spoke with Julia today for about 40 minutes. She’s a little strange, personality wise. Somewhat scattered, I’d say. But in fairness, I goofed and called her a day early, so she wasn’t exactly prepared. That might also excuse that she didn’t seem to know anything about me. She also said a few things that, even if true, were a little odd to bring up. For example, she mentioned that part of the reason she left McDermott is that another partner at the firm was spreading false rumors that she was having an affair with a senior partner, and she couldn’t take that level of drama. Also, she is apparently anti-Peloton for some reason. Doesn’t really matter. Just something that came up ?

But somehow, she grew on me through the conversation, and my impression changed of her from simply a little odd, to maybe someone who is a genuine person who doesn’t have the best filter. Substantively, she indeed seems to be what we’re looking for, a real privacy lawyer through and through, who can meet the vast majority of our needs in this area. She has solid clients marquis clients (like S&P Global), and feels that $1M is reliable. She is ultimately looking for a place the she enjoys working, feels part of a team. She said it meant a lot to her that Michael and I both spoke to her directly, and that she gets a warm impression from having spoken to us – she seemed to genuinely appreciate the outreach. (Interestingly, she also said that she spoke to some folks at Fisher, but that they just didn’t seem like nice, genuine people. Strange that we seem to be hearing this a lot lately.)

The other really odd thing was that she communicated anxiety over losing her guaranteed comp, and that this was the biggest factor in stopping her from making a move. Fortunately, I asked her to do some math with me together. She is currently earning $425k, and she mulled that “I’d have to earn 1.2M at Rimon to earn that, and I feel like I’m solidly at 1.” I jumped in to say, that math doesn’t sound right – you’d have to do 607k to reach that number. She seemed genuinely surprised, and realized that she’d been making a big mistake in her calculations. Perhaps that’s concerning. Perhaps she just wasn’t thinking about it much. But her tone immediately changed, and she suddenly seemed eager to make something happen. She will work on the LPQ and get it back to us very soon (so she says). She also needs to get back to Jeff Fromm.
Closing Reason: Chose to stay at current firm
Private Management Notes:
Julia remains very interested in Rimon but she has had a couple of issues that has required her to delay coming on board.  First, she has been caring for her 93 year old mom.   However, that is not the main reason she needed to delay.  Her largest client S&P Global merged with another entity.  As a result, her billings for that client dropped from $30k to $5k/month.  The same happened to her second largest client, ZipWhip and her billings went from $15-20K/month to $5k/month.

Since these setbacks, she has started to build up her client base again.  She added Coca Cola (her friend at S&P moved to Coke) and is now billing them $30k/month.

She wants us to continue to put things on hold for now, but asked that we touch base in one month (I added a task).  Once she feels comfortable with the stability of her clients, she wants to join us.

Title: Partner
Private Management Notes:
Added notes from Fred Chang 3/2/21:
I know Xiaowei is still looking at the Hainan angle (sidetracked due to COVID), and not sure what the Firm interest level in opening up in Shanghai is, given the application process (and having to juggle multiple irons in the fire in terms of permission to have two law firm offices in China). My feeling is that once Xiaowei with my and others’ assistance gets Hainan moving, Rocky in and of himself is no reason to distract from our goal. Xiaowei would know whether we could simultaneously open an office in Hainan and one in Shanghai, but the latter is notoriously oversaturated.

My observations of practice in China leads me to believe that no one lawyer can start a standalone deal or litigation practice in China that can compete in a crowded market without both (a) a team and (b) an office, so you are right, there would be significant costs associated with starting an office in a place like Shanghai. There is the possibility that he could, singlehandedly without a team but probably still requiring an office, be a significant source of referrals to our US offices. My take would be to suss out whether (a) he needs, and can bring, a team in order to realize his own book and (b) he is able to refer work. I think he has the burden of proof on this.

I did some checking with old friends at Lovells (now Hogan Lovells). They gave me lukewarm feedback on Rocky. While he may have developed a strong practice in the five years since he was there, I think it would increase his already significant burden of proof.

Needs Office?: Willing to work from home and see how it goes
Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
Steve Eichel's initial thoughts:
While Marc has what I would consider to be a reasonably impressive resume if I were looking for a mid-to-senior-level tax associate, I see some of the subtle clues that generally indicate that he is probably not yet the type of “first chair” attorney who would really have achieved a half-million-dollar book of business that he had truly originated himself.

The “representative matters” described strike me as too granular and disparate in subject matter to suggest a deep enough core practice focus to have the kind of credibility in the marketplace that would support that level of revenue consistently.  For example, it does not strike me as likely that a single tax attorney would be handling both international tax issues involved in inbound entry of foreign companies into the U.S. market while at the same time handling fairly esoteric Rhode Island state and local tax issues, along with IRS audits on worker classification issues, UBTI and 409A and ERISA issues.  No one could possibly cover all those highly diverse and unrelated areas competently, particularly only 13 years out of law school.  I don’t know Marc and haven’t heard of Marc, and my comments above are not to say that he might not be a perfectly fine budding tax attorney.  Rather, in my experience, taking all of the facts I can glean from his resume in the aggregate, I have trouble believing that he is really as he is being presented by the recruiter—an established rainmaker with a substantial portable book of business—as opposed to a developing tax and/or business attorney who has had a wide range of experiences and projects in many diverse areas while he figures out a long-term focus for his career.  I just get the sense that there is some substantial puffing going on here in terms of what he has “worked on” (for what is likely other originators) versus work that he has actually generated on his own.  I could certainly be wrong, but that’s my first impression for what it’s worth.

PRIVATE: Sent 9/18/20 by Manaf:
Figures regarding the expenses we anticipate to be included in the 30%:
- Offices : 250 square meters (1 open space for all the lawyer regardless of their status/seniority and 1 meeting room): 150,000€
- Marketing expenses: 25,000€/annum
- Client events: 20,000€/annum
- Trade association: 20,000€/annum

- liability insurance (if there a way to use the Rimon global insurance, that works for us)
- legal websites costs (Lexis Nexis, electronic closing sites.
The last two are not significant enough to be assessed at this stage.

Obviously, from the list of things covered by the 30% in the US, if some of them are applicable (one time travel for partners, tools, etc.) many of them are not applicable to us (example: medical insurance, US located services...). So this might constitute an economy for the firm. 

All the above expenses are going to be increased with those related to the required installations for the offices such as the furnitures, the hardware/software etc. (but these are one time expenses).

Our plan is to prepare a move with 2/3 more partners (which we are currently selecting) in order to be able to cover all the banking and finance (transactional ans regulatory) and Africa related issues, and generate a minimum of 2M€/annum as a start. Further recruitments will follow once good and profitable profiles are selected. It’s easier to attract the best profiles while the firm is up and running.

I did a little additional digging on Zhun.  First, I spoke with Letao.  She confirmed that she recommends Zhun and believes that he made a mistake in deciding to join Offit. I then spoke with Jason Klein, who had worked at Offit.  Jason confirmed that it was “quite possible” that Offit’s back office messed up Zhun’s ability to docket patent matters, thus leading to Zhun’s frustration and desire to leave the firm after only a few months.  Jason stated that Offit did not have much of, if any, a patent prosecution practice and expressed surprise that Zhun would’ve decided to go there in the first place.  I think it might be helpful for Zhun to speak with Jason and have Jason provide us with his thoughts.

From Zhun, on updated numbers 5/17/21:
I looked over the numbers during the weekend and believe the 2020 collected fees from my originations should be adjusted to $837 for reasons listed below:
1. The $44k collected fees from my originations were based on the snapshot I saw on Jan. 12, 2021 and my last date with Faegre Drinker was Jan. 15 (Friday), 2021.  But I could not tell which client(s) paid those fees (as the combined Faegre Drinker firm, after about a year of integration (starting Feb. 1, 2020), moved towards a more "closed" system.         
2. As I was getting ready to change firms from the end of 2020 to the beginning of 2021, that $44k collection as of Jan. 12, 2021 could not possibly be from the work done in the first 12 days of Jan. 2021.  My starting day at Offit Kurman was Jan. 19 (Tuesday) because Monday, Jan. 18 was a holiday, and no longer had access to Faegre Drinker numbers after Jan. 15, 2021.  
3. Legacy Drinker's fiscal year used to end on Jan. 31, which was the basis for all my data provided for 2019 and 2018 (and the numbers mentioned for 2017 and 2016). But the combined Faegre Drinker firm shifted the end of fiscal year to Dec. 31, starting in 2021.  To be consistent with my 2019, 2018, and earlier data, the payment amounts arrived in Jan. 2021, should be accounted as a part for my 2020 originations.  
4. Assuming in the remaining 18 days in Jan. 2021 where the same payment amount of $44k came in to Faegre Drinker from my originations, then my total amount of collected originations for 2020 should be 749k (as of Dec. 31, 2020) + 44k (as of Jan. 12, 2021) +44k (as of Jan. 31, 2021) = 837k (or a little higher).

Title: Partner
Notes on Conflicts Check: All clear on the conflicts side - including after receiving updated LPQ 4/26/21.
Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
Regarding lawsuits, notes from JZ:
- There are really 2 claims, not 4.
- One claim relates to Benjamin’s role as a real estate entrepreneur in a project gone bust during the crisis.  These 2 claims should not be counted against him.
- The other claim has various serious allegations against Benjamin which, if true, would disqualify him.  On the other hand, there are enough underlying parts of the story that indicate that he was caught in the middle and was trying to be creative to come up with solutions to save a project.  I can’t render a conclusion without more facts.
- During the 2003-2007 time frame, the Mexican real estate market was very hot and everyone was making money (a rising tide).  However, when the crisis hit, a lot of projects that had bad management or were under capitalized or were just in weaker markets went under.  At the time, I was heavily involved with Paladin and we had 3 JV’s blow up and 2 went into very ugly litigation.  Our had several very ugly messes that took several years to unwind, including insurance claims, bail-outs and restructurings which required a lot of creative planning.  We also had disgruntled home and lot buyers who threatened litigation to try to recover cash deposits which developers had spent on permitting and legit capital expenses.  At the end of the day, I’d like to withhold judgment of Benjamin because the vibe that I got was not of a shyster lawyer, but rather a very high level professional

Title: Senior Asscoiate/Partner
Notes on Conflicts Check:
No entities listed on LPQ - see note below from recruit:
"Given that I cannot guarantee any portable business should I be invited to join Rimon, I thought it might be helpful to set out my preliminary thoughts on building a book of business."
Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
Yaacov's notes 5/16/21:
We have to assume that we would lose money on this candidate alone, and that losses will be bearable. So the real questions I'd ask is whether (a) adding Mike will actually help us recruit profitable lawyers in the UK and (b) whether Mike will actually stay if he can't generate business. We're obviously keen to suffer the same sort of fate as our competitors who have opened in the UK only to fizzle out pretty quickly.

Scott's reply 5/16/21:
1.	Roger and I think the trickiest step in building London is probably the first partner hire and starting to build a core.  Mike would obviously be of help with that.
2.	On costs,  under our Agreement we would be entitled to a £10k advance placement fee if Mike joins.  We never intended it to work this way if the first partner we placed has no day one book.  We are happy to waive the advance payment for Mike and rely on the 15%.  As regards office space, I’m pretty sure Mike intends to work remotely (he lives in Bath which is not a sensible regular commute) – I can check this with him if it would assist.
3.	On Yaacov’s questions -
(a) will Mike actually help us recruit profitable lawyers in the UK? The answer is that he is a first step.  If we recruit him, Petar and a couple of others we will have a nucleus which should act as a springboard.
(b) will Mike stay if he can't generate business – I think the real question is whether Mike will generate business – I wouldn’t expect anyone to stay if they can’t generate business.  There’s a reasonable prospect he will generate business but it’s not a slam dunk. If he leaves after say 18 months and has enabled us to build the office with other profitable lawyers in the meantime I don’t think it matters – building the office with other profitable lawyers of course does matter.

Roger's input 5/16/21:
I would like to think that as a start he should be able to seek to develop business and target the handling of matters without incurring such costs. I wouldn’t have thought that Rimon should invest in research tools and the like until a request backed by a business case comes forward. Presumably some types of support if needed eg paralegals and document management could be provided from other locations particularly the US? If yes, we can highlight this to Mike-I think I already mentioned this possibility on one of the VCs with him
