Title: Partner
Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
On flux of book, from Steve 3/15/21:
I had three (maybe four) months in the low year that were dedicated to preparing to try a case in Judge Hoffman’s court. This was a contingency case, so we do not collect any proceeds until all appeals are resolved. We obtained a jury verdict of $6.6 Million, plus reasonable attorneys’ fees, and taxable costs, all of which the Firm gets about 30%. It was recently affirmed on appeal by the Dallas Court of Appeals. The defense says they will pursue a petition with the Texas Court of Appeals.

In other years, I had more billable time so the numbers are higher.

If I have to try the patent case against the government and its military contractors who are implementing security systems at military and civilian locations, including nuclear missile installations, the amount of time needed may be high, the risk will be high, but the potential benefits are also very high. That lawsuit involves more than $100 Million in claims damages. As previously indicated, we have litigation financing for that case of more than $1 Million remaining for the experts. I can’t accurately forecast whether the case will settle or require a trial.

Private Management Notes:
Per Manny regarding originations, 5/17:
I originated all the work in Attachment A, and I did all the work on those matters.  And I currently have a 100% collection rate for the matters listed.  A reason for this is a big percentage of my state/federal white collar practice consists of flat fees up front, which facilitates collections immensely.  I do my due diligence before quoting a flat fee to a client.  This, in conjunction with my efficiency and experience, often results in a very high hourly in a flat fee case.  Quick example: let’s say I’m retained for $10k flat fee to research if a client’s business model contravenes bank and/or money laundering laws, and I only need to spend four hours on the matter.  The client is happy knowing there’s a top limit on what I’ll be charging, and I earn approximately $2500 per hour for the work I did.
Upon leaving my current position I’ll be bringing with me approximately $400k in portable business.  Further, I have two significant federal white collar matters I’m defending, both going to jury trial within the next 12 months as my clients have declined the U.S. Atty’s plea offers.  Each trial will generate fees in the vicinity of $350-500k.  Going with the conservative $350k figure, times two, that comes out to approximately $700k for the two federal criminal jury trials.  That $700k added to my $400k portable business I’m bringing with me accounts for the estimated $700k-$1m book.
Welcome & Collaboration Committe:
Zheng: "Very likely to be able to work with Manny Medrano in white collar criminal matters in CA"

Also include: JEZ
Closing reason details: Start date 02/18/22
Interest in Rimon - Long Form: Manny likes that Rimon is based in California, and that the largest concentration of lawyers are in CA. He also likes the fact that Rimon only has 4 partners who practice white collar in states outside of CA.
Admin Support -Long Form:
Generally, I'll staff a white collar matter that's going to trial with 2-3 attys (associates and/or partners, depending on level of trial experience), a paralegal, and a litigation assistant. I'm very open to mentoring and working with senior associates to give him/her trial experience.  

On white collar matters that are at the pretrial/plea negotiations stage, I generally will utilize 1 atty and paralegal.  Much depends at this early stage on the quantity of discovery.
Associate Work - Long Form: He would be coming alone, but might be inclined to use some of his support from associates from other firms if he could not use appropriate support from other Rimon attorneys. He has lots of contacts he could bring to the Rimon Alliance as contract lawyers at the beginning.

Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
One question he raised is about the compensation model, which obviously rewards billing on matters. I told him I don’t pretend to have the answers, but I thought in some ways he might have flexibility, for example:
•         If he can maintain the same billing rates at Rimon, could he establish appropriate internal billing rates such that “his” portion, after the firm’s share and whoever is doing the work, can fairly compensate him?
•         Related points: what do his team receive now in comp and what do they need? With our model, conceivably the team could work fewer hours for the same or similar comp to what they’re getting today.
•         Might there be other ways his team could be dealt with on “team matters”? For example, could they be a single economic unit for team matters and then he allocates comp as makes sense? There are challenges to this – including integration with the rest of the firm – but my sense is that, even if we assume his team bills “only” $8mm (less than what they did last year, and he thinks his group could be closer to 10 this year), the aggregate of $5.6mm is more than what the entirety of the team is getting paid now.
•         Maybe there are other ways to think about this?
Private Management Notes:
MBM Notes: They would come as a financial group - not sure if they would form their own entity or not. Joe is concerned that other partners will want salaries, so we discussed the idea of keeping money in their account when times are good to cover for times that are slow. Spreadsheet is going to be key here. If they make money and cover risk, they are likely to join.

His hourly rate is in the high $700s.

•         Might there be other ways his team could be dealt with on “team matters”? For example, could they be a single economic unit for team matters and then he allocates comp as makes sense? There are challenges to this – including integration with the rest of the firm – but my sense is that, even if we assume his team bills “only” $8mm (less than what they did last year, and he thinks his group could be closer to 10 this year), the aggregate of $5.6mm is more than what the entirety of the team is getting paid now.
•         Maybe there are other ways to think about this?

Title: Partner
Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
Per Warren 1/21/22:
There seems to be two options, namely (a) “in association with Rimon” where we jointly market and have a fee share arrangement or (b) a referral fee arrangement. 

In relation to the first option, there could be a fee share arrangement where the “fees under management” principle would apply – the originating partner would manage the client relationship, send out the work once done, payments etc and receive a percentage / portion of the fees as agreed, while the partner (team) doing the work would invoice the originating firm for the agreed fees. We have found that this works very well for overseas firms that charge in USD, GBP etc because we would charge our normal rates in ZAR – the SA rates are generally lower than other jurisdictions and there is always headroom between what, for example Rimon, would charge its clients, and what we would charge to do the work. To make it work the other way around, we would discuss and agree a fee for the work done by the Rimon team, and we would add a BVI fee as agreed with the BVI client.

The second option would be based on an agreed referral fee (probably an agreed percentage) which would be paid across.

Private Management Notes:
Per Mauro 01/02/22:
The current agreement that I have with CMS is to split 50/50 the first 500,000 euro collected by CMS from my clients; above 500,000 Euro, I get 100% of any payment from my clients; on top of that, I get 35% of the work on CMS clients (but this amount is negligible as I’m not getting referrals from CMS).

CMS is paying my associates (current annual cost is Euro 150,000, including bonus), office staff, lease/rent for the office, pc and basically I have no other costs to bear to run my activity. 

CMS office is in Milan downtown near the Duomo. 

In order to incentivize the flow of work from Rimon network, I’m prepared to split differently Rimon's flow of work, in the sense that I’m prepared to get 35% of collections on referrals while 65% is to the benefit of Rimon.

Title: Partner
Closing Reason: Book was not high enough;Level of excellence was lacking
Private Management Notes:
Per Ben Aguilera 3/21/22:
In as much as it would be “nice” to have an office in Mexico, I do not think it would be in Rimon’s best interest to open it with an attorney that does not have a book of business or a high level profile.  I’ve known Alberto Bringas for about 15 years and he is a capable but not a high caliber attorney plus, unfortunately, Hermosillo and the whole state of Sonora are not jurisdictions with high potential clients 
(I think there is only one publicly traded company in the state – Bachoco – a chicken producer, but its success was due to heavy political support as a former governor (Ricardo Bours) is a member of the family that owns it and a former very powerful senator from that state also had been rumored to have a stake in it).  And politically speaking right now, Sonora’s new governor is from the ruling Socialist party known as MORENA, not a very entrepreneurial, capitalist platform, actually, quite the opposite, so I don’t see Sonora being a place for foreign investment in the near future.  I used to have 4 or 5 deals in Sonora at any time over my first 20 years of practice but I haven’t had a single transaction in Sonora in the last 3 to 5 years.

Notes from Fed Salinas
•	It’s been a while since I dealt with Wayne. He was a newly made up partner at Weil London and I was a senior associate in the late 1990s. We were both cap markets. We worked together very closely for nearly a year on the privatization via IPO of the largest insurance company in Poland and also on a few high yield offerings.
•	Wayne is smart and articulate. 
•	Like many of us who came to London from NYC in the late 1990s/early 2000s, we rode the wave of American investment banking power and acquired huge experience in EMEA cap markets (high yield debt, IPOs, etc)
•	The world has changed and the relationships and skill sets of the UK-based US lawyer are not as relevant to the current landscape as they used to be
•	A lot of the EMEA investment banking has moved already from the UK to the EU
•	Even UK-based UK lawyers are having and will continue to have a diminished role in EU/EMEA deals
•	Investment banking deals in general are not what they used to be and the role of the US lawyer is less important than it used to be
•	Unless Wayne has developed new skill sets and relationships that are not dependent on US investment banking, I am not sure what he could add

Olivier's note 3/5/21:
Let me clarify the numbers:
•	The Swiss firm billed for CHF 2,343,268 ($ 2,545,000) last year, including around CHF 1,200,000 ($ 1,300,000) from my team. 
•	The US firm billed $ 676,287.20 
•	However, it included an amount of $ 640,424.68 paid by the Swiss firm to the US firm. 
•	In summary, the total of my team’s turnover was $ 1,335,000 in 2020. 
•	Because I am attending an LL.M. program, I expect this number will be a little lower this year. I plan to realize with my team a turnover of $ 1,200,000.

Yaacov: He still maintains a full-time office in Lausanne. We would not want to pay for this.
He still maintains a full-time office in Austin, at a cost of about $4,500/month. It has three offices and a conference room. And it’s just him! And he lives in a huge house, and he almost never sees clients. So query why he maintains and pays for this. We would not want to.
It would be a short avenue toward having an office in Switzerland, but I’m not sure it’s in our long-term best interests on these terms. To begin, we’d have no resident partner in Switzerland, just two associates, neither of whom has BD skills. We’d obviously associate Olivier with the office, but I’m not sure that he’s sophisticated attorney that we need to be our founding partner. He has basically only ever worked for one tiny firm before starting his own practice. So doesn’t have the years or depth of experience to be a draw to future partners. He also spoke about the mistakes he made in opening the US firm, admitting that he really didn’t understand the US market, etc. So he’s kind of neither her nor there.
Claim is that he has 1.2M business that was attributable to him last year. But he expects it to be less this year (I don’t know how much) and he said he really needs to undertake BD efforts to build a practice, etc.
If we simply a young and hungry Texas attorney, in some ways that might make an easier case. He likely has a decently solid book that can grow. But it might be a little harder to deem him a full partner. And harder still to use him for the opening of a foreign office. I worry about that the most.
 
If we can pull it off, I think my recommendation would be that we need him to bring an additional, qualified, local partner in Switzerland as part of the package. I already primed him for that.

1.	My two Swiss associates and I made around CHF 1,240,000
2.	My partners (Danilo et Sylvain), who left the firm on January 1, 2021, made around CHF 1,054,000
3.	We charge our clients 3% lump sum out-of-pocket expenses for a total of CHF 73,000
4.	The total Swiss law firm turnover was around CHF 2,368,000
 
Therefore, my turnover with my two associates in Lausanne for 2020 was CHF 1,240,000, plus around CHF 37,000 out-of-pocket. Therefore, the total was around CHF 1,277,200. I expect to have similar numbers with my team this year. Of course, the turnover of Danilo and Sylvain is gone. 
 
This first quarter, our turnover with my two associates in Lausanne was around CHF 270’000. It was a little less than last year. However, I am attending a full-time LL.M. program at UT. Therefore, I am thrilled with these numbers. Furthermore, I expect to make more during the second semester, when I will have finished my LL.M. program. I expect to compensate the delta and reach my year goal, which is CHF 1,200,000.

3.28.22 If joining please rerun conflicts
-YPS pinged Lorne re: Goldman 12/15.
-Lorne response to YPS re Goldman: That shouldn’t be a problem unless we were suing them for fraud or bad faith or something like that. We normally treat lenders like Goldman, BofA, etc as neutral parties in our conflicts analysis on the theory that we are not really adverse to the lender because we are not representing the borrower on the loan docts or negotiating deal terms.   All we are doing is reviewing certain covenants in the Loan Agreement and checking the borrower’s organizational structure and organizational documents for the purpose of providing a reasoned opinion on the possibility of a substantive consolidation under existing bankruptcy concepts and case law. In my engagement letters I also make it clear to the borrower that we sometimes represent these lenders and may be opposite the borrower or it’s affiliates in matters unrelated to the transaction involving our opinions and get their consent to do so. If that’s an issue I don’t take on the assignment.  I will send you a copy of my typical engagement letter.

-Boston Properties/EdiGene hit: Reach out to Greg Krafka. Waivers might be needed.
Closing Reason: Chose to stay at current firm;Other

Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
ESW (6/29):  Jason has been asked to leave Faegre Drinker by 9/30/22.  He says that despite being on track to originate $1M this year (in the previous two years it was $1.6M and in '19 it was closer to $2.6M due to two large class actions) the firm wanted to let him go because of his salary (he currently makes $600k) and the fact that he bills less than 1000 hours/ year -- opting instead to farm out work to other partners (26 in the past year).  He does first chair nationwide class actions but the two large class actions he had both settled in 2020.  He said that Drinker has a 1650 hour billable requirement and he has not billed close to that in a couple of years.  He also said that despite giving plenty of work to others at his firm, he has gotten zero in reciprocation.

This seems very odd to me.  Why would a firm not want a rainmaker who gives work to other attorneys?  Thus, this is a tough call.  He was very forthright and told me that everyone he knows cannot believe how "stupid" Faegre is being.  But it just strikes me as suspicious (even though he said nothing else).  If he were to join, it would be around 10/1/22.

Jason also indicated that he has close relationships with his clients but is not 100% sure his entire client base will follow him.  He said he will approach his clients in the coming weeks once he has a better sense of where he might be landing.

ESW -- CONSERVATIVE book number ($700,000) is Jason's own estimate of his first 12 months with Rimon - from his LPQ.  His numbers are much better than that over the past three years so he is seems to have decided to be very conservative

Their practice includes patent prosecution, counseling, licensing and litigation (they consider themselves IP litigators, not necessarily trial attorneys). They have about 200 patent prosecution cases with about half active as well as U.S. and foreign trademark and copyright patent infringement and invalidity cases. Prior to joining, Lewis Roca, they were with Greenberg Traurig (New Jersey and Phoenix), McCarter & English and have also had their own firm. They appear to be very entrepreneurial and have innovative ways to practice and develop business. They are committed to staying in Phoenix as they see it as a future burgeoning area for IP. Their dissatisfaction with their current firm is that their billing rates are very high, there is little to no collaboration or support (which is what they were promised), poor integration into the firm and lots of committees and red tape. They are actively interviewing and are interested in looking closer at Rimon's platform. They are confident that all of their clients would follow them. They also believe that they could attract more partners to the firm.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Call with Ed, 4/3/23

Doug Lalone seems to be a perfect fit for Rimon. He is a true legal entrepreneur, who uses a business coach and data-driven analytics to attempt to increase his client base.

His practice is comprised of four buckets:  (1) IP procurement (registering patents, trademarks and copyrights); (2) IP litigation (he first chairs many cases and currently has cases in TX, NC and UT); (3) Strategic IP (counseling clients to keep the competition at bay); and (4) M&A transactional IP work (due diligence, buy/sell agreements).

He cross sells M&A work, cannabis and beverage/alcohol licensing work.  This work is referred outside of his firm.  Most of his inbound referrals come from non-lawyers so he is not concerned about joining a full-service firm.

Doug would need one full-time associate and a patent paralegal (only a few hours per week but that can increase depending on the status of his litigation matters).  

Doug has averaged close to $1.5M for the last 9 years, dropping to $800K last year but on pace for $1.2M in 2023 (he has added 10 new clients this year already).  His hourly rate is $650.

Doug is leaving his firm because there is a toxic cult of personality at his firm that he cannot resolve.  Many partners and associates have left the firm.  

Doug wants to move immediately (May 1) and I think he would be an A+ addition to Rimon.
Secondary Practice Group: Trade secret, unfair competition, domain name, non-compete,copyright infringement claims

Rimon Initial Interview:
Video Call with ESW 4/17:

Brian Keeler is a corporate M&A partner who has been with MLB (by way of Bingham) for many years.  His practice has involved representing funds (PE and others) in M&A and other corporate transactions.  

His two main PE clients are winding down.  He believes his clients going forward will be non PE clients and he will experience significant rate pressure (his current rate is $1515). 

Last fiscal year (MLB does September fiscal years) he did $1.765M.  In the first half of this fiscal year he has done $500k.  However, Brian said a lot of work coming from his non-PE clients (who again are winding down and will no longer be clients) is not recurring.  He couldn't say whether $300k, $750k or over $1M would be his numbers if he were to join Rimon.

Because his two main clients are winding down, Brian is at "60% FTE."  He has an 1100 hour billable requirement and he is on pace for 500 although he said he has a $400-550M M&A deal that is beginning and his hours will pick up.

Brian does not need an office and utilizes minimal paralegal support.  He does use associates and the amount varies depending on the size of his deals.  He said he has a hard time delegating work and likes to do the work himself.

Brian cross sells litigation (he has a class action suit based in London) and also other practice areas that are required for M&A deals (particularly tax but also ERISA, environmental, real estate).  

Brian says his work comes to him through referrrals - he has not marketed himself.

Brian said moving is "less than 50/50" and he would not move until at least September 2023.  He wanted a couple weeks to consider Rimon.

I am on the fence on this one.  Brian clearly is a good corporate partner but it is hard to know how much work he would port (and then generate) if he were to join Rimon.

Jeff would like to increase the number of US clients the firm has.

Jeff said he is "burned out" and wants to have a clear succession plan (Jeff is the 100% owner of the firm and said he does not want to practice more than another 4-6 years).

Mark does not seem to do any work himself.  HE said he worked for the Crown Prince in Dubai (named as a "Dubai Future Fellow") and then retired for awhile in his late 40s.  He is 50 now and wants to work because he enjoys it (he said he does not need the money).

He would look to join Rimon so that European and Mid-East Rimon partners could do work he generates from client contacts but it does not seem possible for Rimon to be able to handle this work.   He also wanted Rimon to consider folding his Kazakhstani firm (Seven Pillars) into Rimon.

Mark also offered Rimon to help build out Europe and the Middle East (he did not mention getting paid to do this, but I sense that would be coming).

I simply don't think Mark would be a good fit.

Rimon Initial Interview: Jeff Toppel is a partner with the law firm of Farhang & Medcoff in Phoeniz, AZ. Prior to joining Farhang & Medcoff, Jeff helped open the Phoenix office of Jackson Lewis where he practiced for almost 15 years. Jackson Lewis is a boutique firm and because of changes in management, Jeff had to refer out a lot of non-L&E work. Jeff decided to join a smaller firm where the founders were old friends and where he would have more control over his business development and client base. Jeff does most of his own work with help from a paralegal. About 50% of Jeff's matters are employment related litigation (including wrongful termination and discrimination claims). The rest of his practice includes advice and counseling, practicing before the NLRB and some commercial litigation. His clients include medical practices, cannabis and wellness companies, multi-housing related businesses, technology companies and insurance companies (not insurance defense). He also represents a very large national healthcare company (DayTryp Health) and some high-level CEOs. Jeff's current challenge is that his clients need other support (corporate/transactional, commercial litigation, estate planning and tax) that his current firm is not able to effectively service.  He is realizing that his current platform doesn't make the most sense long term and will hinder him in growing his client base. Jeff's portable book is $600k and he is projecting $700-900k by the end of 2023. He believes he would be able to increase his current rates ($375-$450) and also use alternative fee arrangements on Rimon's platform. He thinks he may want to make a move by the end of the year but is not wedded to that and might consider moving earlier to the right firm.  Jeff's personable and thoughtful and could make a nice addition to our L&E practice. Although Jeff is early in his process, he is genuinely interested in Rimon.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed & T.J. 7/12:

Robert Keeling has a unique practice. He co-chairs Sidley's e-discovery practice.  He and his team of four others (two counsels, two contract attorneys) are hired by companies facing antitrust matters brought by the government to be "e-discovery counsel."  He works in conjunction with other firms, who act as trial counsel (this is 90% of his matters).  Robert gets very little internal referrals from his Sidley partners.

Robert's matters are a "sprint" and are "episodic."  His team can be working 250 hours/month for 3-4 months at a time on a large e-discovery and then, when depositions start, trial counsel takes over and Robert's team is mostly done.  He can then go several months without the next "big one," and his hours drop to around 50-80/months during those times.

For the large e-discovery matters, Robert often employs 70-80 contract atttorneys who do the initial doc reviews and priviledge logs.  He also utilizes sometimes 30-40 Sidley associates to do quality control on the contract lawyers.   It is this last piece that would recuire significant thought were Robert to come to Rimon.

One idea (T.J.) was that Robert could partner with another firm (perhaps based in the Midwest where rates are lower) who can do QC since Rimon doesn't have the manpower.

Robert says he is grossly undercompensated at Sidley and his mandated bill rate is $1,250.  This rate is pricing him out of being able to do smaller matters and is contributing to the episodic nature of his practice.

Robert would be a fantastic candidate.  There are many moving parts here and we will have several additional discussions as we proceed.  Robert is not actively looking to move (he's been with Sidley for his whole 28 year career and has spoken with only one other firm that was a nonstarter) and does not have a timeframe.  But he said Rimon's comp. model is the "fairest" he has ever seen.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Cody Wamsley is a personable privacy/data security partner candidate.  He was most recently at Coinbase, having been there for eight months during a hiring spree but was laid off (3rd round) in January 2023.

Cody's boss, the Director of Security - Legal, remains at Coinbase.  The Director came to Coinbase from Facebook/Meta along with a number of other C-Suite execs.  The Director went on paternity leave soon after Cody joined Coinbase and Cody handled all security legal work.

The Director has specifically told Cody that once he lands at a new firm, Coinbase will provide a large portion of their $1.3M security budget to Cody.  As a floor, Cody's direct supervisor at Coinbase has promised Cody, as recently as two weeks ago, $400-500k in incident response work and $200-300K in security compliance.   There is a definite possibility that more of the budgeted amount could be sent to Cody's new firm as well (regulatory compliance, international security).  

Additionally, Coinbase's privacy legal budget is $3-4M.  Cody believes he and his new firm could capture some of that work as well.  There is also litigation and other regulatory work currently sent to other firms that Cody believes he could capture with the help of his new partners.

Cody also believes he could bring in 3M as a client.  Cody was secunded to 3M when he was an associate at McDonald Huges and when he left McDonald and joined Dorsey, he generated $800k in business from 3M.  Cody says he has many other prospective clients and intends to widely market his expertise upon arrival at a new firm.

One concern is that Cody has moved around a lot, although he had good reasons for doing so.  He graduated law school in 2008 and for the first few years in practice he was a contract IP consultant for start-up companies.   In 2013 he became the fourth employee at CyberSponse as Director of Legal Affairs and Patent Counsel.   After just over 2.5 years, Cody joined AmEx as an IT Risk and Security Manager.  

After 18 months at AmEX, Cody joined McDonald Hopkins as a data privacy and security attorney.   When he arrived, the managing partner told Cody they expected him to bill 2600 hours.  Cody left McDonald after 10 months to join Dorsey & Whitney in January 2018 as an associate.

At Dorsey, Cody was secunded to 3M where he made several connections and said he eventually landed $800k in privacy work for his firm.  Cody liked Dorsey and would have stayed but the firm cut his pay during the pandemic and he was billing 250 hours/month as one of the only privacy/data security attorneys.  As such, in January 2021, Cody joined Oracle and received a significant raise.

After 18 months at Oracle, Cody was recruited to Coinbase, where he stayed until being laid off at the beginning of 2023.  

Cody expects to be able to charge Coinbase $1200/hour and all other clients $750.

We will need to thoroughly vet Cody since he is coming from in-house and has made so many moves in his career.  But he very well may end up being a good fit at Rimon.

CALL WITH ESW 3/23/23

David advises public and private sector clients on sanctions, AML, FATF evaluations, digital currency regulations and issuances (including CBDCs), government relations, and corporate compliance.

From 2018 to 2020, David served as the Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Counter Threat Finance and Sanctions in the Bureau of Economic and Business Affairs. As the State Department's sanctions chief, David led the Office of Economic Sanctions Policy and Implementation and was responsible for managing 25 sanctions programs for the Secretary of State, including Iran, Russia, China, and Venezuela sanctions. 

In the two years since leaving the State Dept. and joining DLA, David has developed a $1.5M book of business representing multiple international clients including Russia's largest bank, one of Europe's largest pharma companies, a sovereign entity, Greece's largest shipping company.

David's holistic practice runs the gamut of international trade, export control, managing risk/compliance and governmental relations. He has close ties to Israel, Dubai and the UAE and likes that Rimon has a presence in the first two countries.

His main concern is that there are Rimon attorneys who have the expertise to help him on his matters (relations with foreign leadership.  David knows Ivan Komaritsky from DLA and said he could keep him 30-40% busy.  He would also need partners with government, export control and sanctions experience.

David said that last year he had 52 separate attorneys bill time on his maters.

I think David could be a superstar at Rimon and I highly recommend we proceed.

Rimon Initial Interview: Robert (Rob) Orozco is a Partner at Leech Tishman (a full-service mid-size firm) in Los Angeles, specializing in Labor & Employment. His practice focuses on representing employers in wage and hour class actions, including whistleblower claims, internal investigations, disciplinary hearings, and other trials and arbitrations. Robert also conducts Workplace Safety/OSHA seminars and webinars and drafts policies and manuals for his clients. Robert has been practicing almost 30 years. He started out as a public defender and then became a regular defense counsel. He has been doing employment defense work for about 23 years. Prior to joining Leech Tishman in 2019, Robert was with Jackson Lewis. The majority of Robert's clients are large institutional clients, including large insurance companies. Others are traditional companies, construction companies, healthcare facilities, franchises, hospitality clients and several private clients. Robert's 3 largest clients are AIG Life Insurance, RSUI, and Tokio Marine.  He currently has 8-10 active class action cases.  Robert's book was $1.5 million last year, and he is on pace (based on the 1st qtr) for $1.2 this year. He and a paralegal (80%) currently do all of his work. He believes his clients are 90-100% portable. He generally refers work in the corporate, healthcare and patent practice areas. He is active in CMCP and HNBA and interested in the firm's DEI efforts. Robert is disappointed with the limited and inconsistent support he has experienced in a number of areas at his firm including management and technology. The firm is also requiring their attorneys to return to the office. Robert does not believe his current firm is prepared for the future of law. He is also looking for more autonomy and a larger footprint, so that he may continue to grow his book. Robert is personable and humble. We should delve deeper into his previous firm moves.

Rimon Initial Interview:
David Nachman is a named partner in this NY based business immigration firm (they also have offices in Indianapolis and Ft. Lauderdale.  They have five attorneys (three are partners, one of the others is licensed in Canada but practices in the US).

The firm has mostly international clients ("50% India, 50% the rest of the world) seeking to do business in the US.  They do immigration work that allows these entities to send executives and others to the US.  

The firm represents 35-40 mid-sized public companies and dozens of private firms.  Revenues last year was $5.9M.  As with most immigration shops, they usually work on a flat fee basis, collecting $6-10k for E2 visas, $3K for H1Bs, etc. 1/3 of their revenue goes to salaries, 1/3 to other expenses (rent and general overhead).  They have a "large" marketing budget.

The firm is seeking to join a full-service firm to grow from referrals and cross selling (they presently farm out corporate, employment and tax work).

Both T.J. and I liked David a lot and we think this firm is a great potential addition to Rimon.

Title: Partner
Closing reason details: BP accepted an offer to join another firm as a partner in its environment and energy practice.
Cross-Service -Long Form: Minimal
Admin Support -Long Form: Ideally would want 300-400 hours/year of paralegal time.
Associate Work - Long Form: Berj does not have associate help which is one main reason he wants to leave his firm.  As of now he anticipates needing about 500-600 hours/year of associate time which would free him up to market his practice.
Office Space - Long Form: Would want to go into the new NY office occasionally.
Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 6/28/23:  Berj is a seasoned toxic tort/environmental litigator who has a national practice.  He handles CERCLA, RCRA, toxic tort and other litigaiton matters.

Berj's main client is Henkel Corporation, which has endless environmental litigation.  While Berj is not the "relationship partner," the client tries to give as much of this work to Berj as they can and has indicated they will continue to provide him with this work if he moves to another firm.  Berj consistently bills 2200-2500 hours which is not conducive to being able to market and grow his practice.  He has been asking for help from his firm for years and they are not providing any, so he is ready to make a move. 

Henkel should provide around $500-550k in work this year.  He has other clients as well.  The main issue here is billing rates.  Berj's rate for Henkel is $350/hour.  He indicated that there is room to push the rate into the $400s.  Indeed, because Lewis Brisbois is not providing Berj with help, Henkel often goes to other AmLaw firms such as Greenberg Trauig who bills the client a far higher rate.

Berj also does some insurance defense work and the bill rate is in the $250 range.  He is fine to jettison that work, other than one matter for Chubb, which I told him should not be an issue.

Berj is a good candidate, and the only issue is the billing rates.  If he can raise his rates on Henkel into the 4s, I would recommend continuing with his candidacy.

Needs Office?: Willing to work from home and see how it goes
Tell us a little about your clients: Referrals from insurers when the insurers have denied coverage (duty to defend).  Also represents clients thought insurance companies when they have agreed to provide coverage.
How much work do you give to associates: More than one full time associate
What about Rimon is Particularly Excitin: Compensation Structure;Flexibility in billing;People in the firm
Closing reason details: Concerned about support.
Interest in Rimon - Long Form: Jura is good friends with Amy Baker and had a strong grasp of the Rimon model.  She knows she will have more freedom to practice the way she wants and make more money as well.
Cross-Service -Long Form: In addition to her book.  She does not even take credit for cross-referrals because it is too cumbersome at her current firm.  Thus, amount is unkown.
Admin Support -Long Form: Very little assistant support needed.

Office Space - Long Form: Wants an office but doesn't need one.
Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 7/19:

Jura (pronounced "Yura") is a partner at Wilson Elser and good friends with Amy Baker.  She has a strong grasp of Rimon based upon her conversations with Amy.  She knows she will make more $$ and have more freedom to practice at Rimon.

Jura's clients come to her through her extensive insurance company network.  Many of her clients are referred to her by insurers when they deny coverage.  Other clients are through insurers when they agree to defend.  Many of these matters have an IP or technology component.

Jura is a litigator, but she does not vert much like to be a trial lawyer any longer. Mostly, she is a client manager at this point in her career.  She trains others within her firm to handle cases.  Most matters are in FL, TX, CA and NY (Jura is licensed in five jurisdictions).  She would need litigators who are able to handle many cases for her.  We spoke candidly that she may have to go outside of Rimon to other firms as there may not be litigators with bandwidth in the jurisdictions where Rimon has litigators and of course Rimon does not have litigators in every jurisdiction where her cases are.  This will be the main issue to resolve if Jura were to join Rimon.

Jura is a very smart and accomplished lawyer, and she was very pleasant to speak with.   
 She is considering Rimon because her current firm has frozen comp, and it is not providing the level of service commensurate with what she is paying for.  Her group is also losing partners. 

Jura could be a great addition to the firm, but we would need to work out her support needs.

Rimon Initial Interview:
James Sanders is a commercial litigation partner with 17+ years’ experience and a successful small business owner. The firm had been working to expand its practice areas to a full-service firm, but under new management it decided to retrench back to its insurance defense roots which was not a great platform for James. James is now practicing on his own but looks forward to rejoining a firm.

James' primary practice is commercial litigation (1st and 2nd chair experience), but he originates litigation and transactional work on an even basis and serves as outside general counsel to several of his clients. His work is about 60-70% Litigation, 30% Corporate and remainder estate planning for high worth individuals and families. 

James is a part owner in a couple of craft breweries and his clientele includes restaurants, brewers, distilleries, beer and wine distributors, and liquor manufacturers along with startups, real estate developers, and corporations. 

His book is about $850k and billing rates are $400/$500/$550 which are just a cut below the highest rates for local and regional work in St. Louis. James is professional and and all-around nice guy. He would be a great addition to the firm.

Associate Work - Long Form: At DWT Uly utilzed a counsel full-time and also utilized about 1/2 of an associate's time.
Rimon Initial Interview:
Uly is a tech transactions attorney.  He was in-house for several years and in 2021 got recruited to help open the SV offices of DWT.  He said he developed $750k in three quarters of 2021 and $1.3M in 2022, but his two-year contract was not renewed as the firm decided against building up SV.

As of May 2023, Uly is now on his own and has one client - the company in which he used to be in-house.  He expects to bill and collect $300k this year from that client.  He handed off all of the rest of his clients and has no other active clients but says he has a large list of contacts (including in China and Japan (he used to do work for Toshiba) and "guessed" that he could hit $1M in his first year. 

Uly usually charges his clients a flat fee.  His rack rate at DWT was $1,200 (avg. rate $930).

Did ramble a bit but I don't know that I doubt his ability to build book nor that he's a good attorney (interviews will be important here). Likes what he heard about culture, growth trajectory, etc. Wife is an attorney who was one of the first people at Occulus. Needs to think about sustaining himself on the model but thinks it's doable. Would move forward.

It is possible that we may need to hire short-term docketing assistance to get their clients on boarded as soon as possible. If so, Tom (Tomoki Tanida) would onboard first and bring his clients over. The group currently uses Inprotech docketing software and iManage. Also uses Anaqua for maintenance fees. Will have Karen Hagerman check into getting Anaqua for the group.
Rimon Initial Interview:
Michael, Takashi and Tom are experienced patent prosecution partners at McDermott.  Michael is the most senior partner and is based in the US.  Tom and Takashi are both Japanese and have clients, prospects and connections in Japan.  Michael has represented Panasonic since the early 90's and Takashi is a former Panasonic employee who has worked with Michael for 15 years. 

Michael's book (Takashi is part of this) is $3M.  Tom's book, comprised of clients other than Panasonic, is $2M.  Michael's hourly rate is $1700, which is completely unsustainable (2/3 of their bills are flat fee arrangements).  They know Japanese clients do not love change and the team has been pushing this off for years, but they know they have to move.

The team is based in DC and would comprise of the three partners, two legal assistants, two patent agents and two paralegals.  

They file over 1000 applications/year and currently have over 3000 active matters that would need to be docketed.  This would be a large-scale project. 

They are talking to other firms but were very enthusiastic about Rimon's model.  This group would be a fantastic addition to Rimon.

Title: Founding partner
Notes on Conflicts Check: Waivers may be required for some of their engagements, based on the scope of their client relationships with clients like Barfield & Marelli and whether the Rimôn partners with work adverse to their affiliates consider it a conflict.
Tell us a little about your clients: IP work for numerous corporate clients across multiple industries.
Interest in Rimon - Long Form: Considering moving because they want to grow.  They have experienced attrition and do not want their group to dissipate.
Cross-Service -Long Form: Minimal Cross-selling.  Would want to increase this if they join Rimon
Admin Support -Long Form:
Firm currently has one part time patent agent/secretary who handles filings, etc.  They pay her $28/hour and she works approximately 10 hours/week.  

They had a para who recently left and they now outsource their paralegal needs.

Firm also has a full-time billing/accounting admin.
Office Space - Long Form: Currently, the firm has a lease in Tysons that is just under 10000 sq. ft.  The rent is $34k/month ($408k/year).  The lease runs through 10/25.  They do not necessarily need office space.  The would be willing to sublease some or all of their space or come up with other creative ways to reduce this cost (including polling our existing NVa lawyers to see if they would be interested in office space).
Rimon Initial Interview:
ESW (5/9):  Don Jackson and Pete Gowdey are part of a seven lawyer "full-service" IP firm (one is semi-retired) in Northern Virginia.  One of their partners is developing work in Japan. 

The firm was founded in 2003 as a spinoff of an other IP firm.  Don is an IP litigator.  Pete is a senior partner who has practiced in big firms (and set up Shook Hardy's IP practice).  The firm has a comp model "similar" to Rimon's.  The partners take all of collections and share in the cost of overhead.  Income from paralegals/patent agents/associates is considered "shared income" and is applied first to overhead.

The group's rates are $600-750/hour and they do discount rates 10-15%.  They said they would be willing to modify their rates to be aligned with the firm they would join.

The firm has experienced attrition and revenue is down.  In '21 the firm collected $2.8M.  In '22 the firm collected $2.4M and this year they are on pace for $2.0M.  They would like to keep their group together.  They think joining a full-service law firm with a deeper IP bench is essential.

Other than the significant office lease expense, the firm's remaining OPEX is minimal (less than $9k/month).  Nevertheless, Don and Pete were not deterred by Rimon's 70/30 split, stating that gaining stability and the ability to service more client work should offset the OPEX discrepancy.

Don and Pete both seem like quality lawyers and if we can make the numbers work they should be an excellent addition to Rimon.  They are currently speaking with several other firms (Rimon was the first firm with whom they spoke).  We told them to have those conversations and agreed to circle back late in the week of 5/22.

Recruit Referral Details: Stuart Tenhoor - Stuart TenHoor Legal Search
Title: Partner
Needs Office?: No, prefer working from home or client's office
Tell us a little about your clients: Small to mid-market pharmaceutical companies.
What about Rimon is Particularly Excitin: Collaboration model;Compensation Structure;Flexibility in billing;Lack of Bureaucracy;Lifestyle
Cross-Service -Long Form: also transportation, reimbursement
Admin Support -Long Form: Neil does not type well and dictates his work, so he relies on legal assistants more than most.  But he did acknowledge that transcription software could work.
Associate Work - Long Form: Neil estimates he needs about 400 associate hours/year.
Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 9/29:

Neil Di Spirito is based in Orlando and runs a sophisticated FDA practice.  His practice has morphed over the years from representing large pharma clients such as Pfizer in large litigations (70-75% of his practice at the time) to representing smaller and mid-sized firms ($600mm) in licensing, transactions, FDA advice and counseling and administrative hearings, critiquing applications, supply chain issues, biologics, pharmaceuticals, etc.  10-15% of his practice remains litigation.  He has also written a textbook, entitled "Bringing Your Drug to Market."

Ed left Brown Rudnick recently and is in the process of setting up his own shop.  He said that the firm wanted him to have a much larger book ("a 2000+ hour practice") but refused to provide him with the resources to do so.  They are paying him through December, but he is no longer on the firm's website.  He said the agreement was "mutual," and he had been planning to "get off the big firm treadmill" for a long time. 

Neil has moved firms in the past few years, having had stints at Ballard and Epstein Becker before joining Brown Rudnick.  He now wants to go solo or join a firm like Rimon.

With his current practice, Neil would not need a ton of resources.  Neil said he would need a subscription to the Westlaw "Pharma Page."  He also speaks at and attends a number of conferences and is part of the FDA Institution, which requires a subscrition fee.

Neil does not need an office.  He uses about 400 hours/year of associate time and rarely uses paralegals.  He does however rely somewhat heavily on a legal assistant because he still dictates his work (there is software that could help).

Neil has cross-sold Corporate, IP, reimbursment, government contracts, environmental and transportation matters.

I liked Neil, and while there is some concern over him leaving Brown Rudnick before joining a new firm, this is outweighed by his obvious expertise and his understanding of what he wants (out of Big Law).  I recommend we continue the process.
Secondary Practice Group: FDA Regulatory law, transactions and litigation

Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 9/20:

James is a fund formation/M&A lawyer who works in funds but also enjoys doing M&A transactions.  He started at Skadden and in 2014 went in-house to Credit Suisse, handling private fund formation and downstream investment work.

In 2022, Credit Suisse was experiencing what are now well-known problems and James moved to Goodwin with the idea that he would start his own practice there.  The problem is that they set his rate at $1400!!! and the rate pressure is the main reason he is looking for a firm with a saner platform.  James is confident he could bring $400-500k with him to Rimon and he could also handle overflow work from other funds partners.  He also would like to continue to be involved with M&As. 

James does most of his own work (he said he uses about 1/3 of a secretary's time).  He would like to have shared office and conference room space but that is not a deal breaker.  He is interested in moving sooner rather than later.

I liked James a lot and think he could be a great addition to Rimon and particularly could take on work that our funds group has been looking to hand off for quite some time.

Recruit Referral Details: John Hatchl - John W. Hatchl & Associates
Title: Associate
Partner
Notes on Conflicts Check: No conflicts found. Per the Conflicts Spreadsheet provided, "no adverse parties known at this time."
Welcome & Collaboration Committe: Joseph Abkin
Interest in Rimon - Long Form: Brian's clients going forward want lower rates than Brian's $1515/hour.
Cross-Service -Long Form: Could not quantify amount.
Admin Support -Long Form: Minimal Paralegal support
Associate Work - Long Form: Utilizes associates on M&A deals.  Amount varies based on size of deal.   Brian does not love delegating work.
Rimon Initial Interview:
Video Call with ESW 4/17:

Brian Keeler is a corporate M&A partner who has been with MLB (by way of Bingham) for many years.  His practice has involved representing funds (PE and others) in M&A and other corporate transactions.  

His two main PE clients are winding down.  He believes his clients going forward will be non PE clients and he will experience significant rate pressure (his current rate is $1515). 

Last fiscal year (MLB does September fiscal years) he did $1.765M.  In the first half of this fiscal year he has done $500k.  However, Brian said a lot of work coming from his non-PE clients (who again are winding down and will no longer be clients) is not recurring.  He couldn't say whether $300k, $750k or over $1M would be his numbers if he were to join Rimon.

Because his two main clients are winding down, Brian is at "60% FTE."  He has an 1100 hour billable requirement and he is on pace for 500 although he said he has a $400-550M M&A deal that is beginning and his hours will pick up.

Brian does not need an office and utilizes minimal paralegal support.  He does use associates and the amount varies depending on the size of his deals.  He said he has a hard time delegating work and likes to do the work himself.

Brian cross sells litigation (he has a class action suit based in London) and also other practice areas that are required for M&A deals (particularly tax but also ERISA, environmental, real estate).  

Brian says his work comes to him through referrrals - he has not marketed himself.

Brian said moving is "less than 50/50" and he would not move until at least September 2023.  He wanted a couple weeks to consider Rimon.

I am on the fence on this one.  Brian clearly is a good corporate partner but it is hard to know how much work he would port (and then generate) if he were to join Rimon.

Rimon Initial Interview:
ESW 8/3:  Group of four partners.  Keith and Gary each have about $1.2M in business.  There are also two non-equity partners, one has about $200k and the other $50K.  The team also includes a paralegal and an assistant who would likely join.  

Group primarily practices T&E.  Keith's book is made up almost entirely of T&E.  Gary's book is 1/2 T&E (and some corporate work he does himself) and 1/2 cross sold - his clients spins off a lot of work outside of that area, including corporate, employment, tax, ERISA, litigation and IP.

At their current firm, the two non-equity partners do work for Keith and Gary but also many others within the firm's T&E group.  Thus, they would not necessarily be fully busy if they group were to join Rimon.  However Keith and Gary believe they are leaving a lot of work on the table which might be enough for both non-equity partners.  Both have "a ton" of client contacts and are both said they too busy to bring on additional work.

Gary and Keith each bill about 1200 hours/year (Gary says $300k is his own work, $300k is delegated and $600k is cross sold; Keith said his book is 1/2 his own work and 1/2 delegated.   

They said they have another 3600 hours of work to give to others (so I think if the two non-equity partners come, they would have enough work).

One issue may be rates.  Keith's is $515, but Gary's is $350 in Southern Illinois and "a little higher" in St. Louis. 

Keith and Gary are considering a move because some of their partners are "toxic."  Associates and others come to the firm and quickly leave because of this.  Additionally, the firm's comp model is a "frustrating black box."

I think this could be a good addition for Rimon.

Ted's book is approximately $800k and his rate is $685.  He has a longtime paralegal whom he would bring with him to Rimon.  I think he would be another great addition to the firm and his practice would fit nicely with David Case and Harold Nathan (who is joining in a couple of weeks).

Doug Stein is MP of a four-person tax and estate planning firm in Atlanta.  That is 90% of his work.  The other 10% is tax opinions, M&A, and some controversy (although he usually refers this work out).  He is considering joining another firm to grow his business and capture cross-selling dollars.

The firm bills its clients with an initial hourly rate to "figure out the matter" which ranges from $650-725 for Doug, $550 for his partner and $300 for his associates, then a flat fee which is $150k or 1.5% of the amount at issue whichever is greater, followed by an hourly rate for "clean up."

Doug said that considering whether to join Rimon would be a "math question." Would he make more money on Rimon's platform based upon cross-selling dollars flowing in each direction or not?   Doug's firm does refer out a lot of work (real estate, litigation ($150-200k/year), tax controversy).  

Doug was very pleasant and he seemed very sharp.  If they want to proceed, I recommend that we do so.

Title: Associate
Needs Office?: No, prefer working from home or client's office
Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed and Sean Byrne 11/15 (Sean's notes):

Ed and I just got off an hour-long call with Gabor. My notes and observations:
•	Looking for a full-time role that pays ~$300k
•	Ed started the call with a good 15-min summary of the firm and its business model. When he asked if Gabor had any questions, Gabor immediately went into the importance of templates and automation to law firm business models. I mention this for two reasons: (i) It came off as a general lack of knowledge of expected social scripts, but also (ii) that he has a background and passion in making templates and automating their use.
•	Regarding templates and automation: his undergraduate degree is in mechanical engineering and from that has a programming background. He claims that at his previous firm, he custom built tools (in Python) to automate docs. Now I don’t know if custom building tools is the right path over using off-the-shelf tools, but it shows some skills to which we rarely have access
•	Has a strong tax background! Before going to law school he became some sort of certified tax preparer (enrolled agent??) and has worked on corporate, partnership, and nonprofit tax returns
•	Has worked with a variety of partnerships, LLCs, and funds. When I mentioned Nicole’s practice he mentioned he worked on launching two crypto hedge funds
•	Has helped a client navigate an SEC audit (roboadvisor) where a big part of it involved SEC-disapproved hedging clauses all over the IAA, terms of service, website language, etc.
•	Has Series 63 and 65 certifications (for what that’s worth)
 
In short, I think he has some unusual skills that could fill some gaps. But I wonder what it is like to work with him. As noted above, he didn’t seem to follow what (in my mind) is the “right” script for an interview. Obviously that could be for a variety of reasons, some fine and some not. I also note that he is undergrad 2003 and JD 2007 (both in Hungary) with US LLM in 2012, but the first law firm job on his resume on LinkedIn is his June 2021-October 2023 stint at Haynes and Boone, so unclear how much law firm experience he has.
 
I don’t think he’s someone to whom we can hand off projects, but he could well be someone that can do a lot of the odd work in fund projects that general corporate associates can’t, such as getting into the weeds on tax or securities law issues, really vetting allocation or distribution waterfalls, or preparing templates or automating them.

Title: Of Counsel
Welcome & Collaboration Committe: Daanish Hamid
Tell us a little about your clients: Sandra's clients span across a variety of industries such as major manufacturers and distributors of imported and exported finished goods and raw materials such as lumber, chemicals, textile and apparel/accessories; automotive vehicles and parts; food products and ingredients; software, industrial coating systems, medical supplies, energy products, luxury consumer goods and professional use products. Sandra's current billing rates at DLA are $1045/$1140/$1200 and most clients are on 30-day net.
What kind of work do you cross-service t: Corporate and Business Transactions;International Transactions;Mergers & Acquisitions
What about Rimon is Particularly Excitin: Associate / Staff Support;Collaboration model;Compensation Structure;International/Regional capabilities;Practice/Sector expertise
Interest in Rimon - Long Form: Sandra likes the transparency of our comp model and the opportunity to collaborate in an open market.
Cross-Service -Long Form: Not quantified
Associate Work - Long Form: At the suggestion of Daanish Hamid, Ivan Komaritsky has met with Sandra regarding providing initial support and Sandra providing training/mentoring.
Office Space - Long Form: Sandra has residences in D.C. and Montgomery, Alabama and travels back and forth. She prefers to be remote but may need to use conference room and/or office space to meet with clients in D.C. from time to time. She would like to be listed under the D.C. office and have a D.C. office phone number.
Other Needs - Long Form: Use ALABAMA as primary residence.
Rimon Initial Interview:
Sandra Bell is an Of Counsel Customs Attorney in the D.C. office of DLA Piper where she has been for the last 7 years. Prior to joining DLA, Sandra held executive government roles including the Deputy Assistant Commissioner in the Office of International Trade and as Executive Director of Regulations and Rulings. Her practice is 90% customs within the international trade field and includes tariff classification, customs valuation, country of origin determinations, import bonding, petitions for illegal penalties, protest decisions, forced labor laws, requests for a ruling, free trade agreements and most issues that touch customs, with the exception of CFIUS. She also has about a 10% mix of regulatory, due diligence checklists, IPR enforcement and cross-border M&A work. Sandra has had extensive experience working in government customs agencies and on the NAFTA working group for developing the U.S. country of origin rules and market access. 

Sandra has not gotten the support she was promised at DLA and the one associate she has working with has been reduced to giving her part-time support. In addition, the firm does not view the international trade practice group as a priority for the firm. Sandra likes the flexibility in rates that Rimon offers (her current billing rates are $1045/$1140/$1200 with pressure to raise them) and was excited to learn about the internal marketplace.  Sandra likes mentoring young associates and would be willing to do so if she joins Rimon. She would likely make a move in January 2024. 

Sandra was very personable and upbeat, extremely knowledgeable in her field and excited about the opportunity to collaborate. Sandra would be a great addition to the international trade practice and her practice would be synergistic with our current attorneys and those that will be joining us in January.
Additional Covered Costs Notes: Recruiter's Fee is 12.5% up front with true-up at year end.

Rimon Initial Interview:
James Min is an equity partner at the law firm of LimNexus. Prior to joining the firm, James was in-house counsel at FedEx and DHL for fifteen years. His decision to go into private practice was largely based on what he had seen in his in-house role of Vice President and Chair for the Trade Law Practice Group in that the company was paying BigLaw firms for trade and sanctions work that was expensive and sometimes not of the quality that the in-house lawyers wanted. He went to the firm with no clients and built a practice of about 6 people and a large book in a matter of five years. 

James' practice focuses on economic sanctions, export controls, customs and import regulations, CFIUS, internal investigations and cross-border transactional and regulatory law. Since 2018, he has been the Co-Managing Partner and Chair for the firm's International Trade Practice Group. His clients are largely Fortune 100 global companies including Comcast, Walmart, Restoration Hardware and Hellmann. 

Collections for 2022: $1.2mm and pacing for 2023: $1.4mm. Rates are $850/hr. James has a great personality and is very entrepreneurial. He says he spent almost 1,000 hours last year doing business development. He is looking for a firm with an international footprint, one that is more collaborative, and fairly compensates you for hard work and innovation. He feels he can grow his book even more on a platform like Rimon. James also speaks Korean and Russian fluently. 

James will be traveling abroad for work at the end of May for 3 weeks but is available for interviews before that time.
Porting Personnel Notes:
Attorney Sponsored Salaries:  

Chelsea Ellis, Associate
Salary - $180k; internal rate - $200

Sarah Kugel, Admin/Legal Asst
Salary - $70k

Rimon Initial Interview:
Mi-Yong Kim is a partner with the D.C. office of LimNexus and has over 25 years of experience in government and private practice related to export controls, international trade, corporate compliance, and national security. She currently practices alongside a current lateral partner candidate - James Min - and he is encouraging her to make the move with him. 

Mi-Yong works part-time (about 15 hours a week); she plans to continue that schedule. Prior to joining LimNexus, she retired from government service where she spent most of her career in the Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) of the U.S. Dept of Commerce in senior level positions and then spent a couple of years as Counsel at Bass Berry & Sims.  Mi-Yong has a mix of U.S., Chinese and Taiwanese clients in a variety of industries including IP and high-tech, semiconductor, medical device, and healthcare and is an expert in export controls.

Mi-Yong is not completely comfortable yet about moving to another firm so quickly (3rd firm and at this point in her career) but enjoys practicing with James. She also wants to hear more about how the internal marketplace works in practice, not just theory. She has been a frequent speaker on export controls and previously wrote several blogs. She is interested in doing both of these things more if she ultimately comes to Rimon. Both would nicely highlight the firm's international trade practice. Mi-Yong is brilliant and witty and would be a great fit in terms of experience and practice. We should do all we can to win her over.

See article: https://www.law360.com/articles/1523362/exporters-should-take-heed-after-dc-circ-s-fedex-ruling

https://www.law360.com/articles/1427537/behind-the-curtain-at-commerce-s-operating-committee

Mi-Yong lives in Alexandria, VA, and to the extent there are interviewing attorneys who might be available for an IN-PERSON meeting in Alexandria or D.C., she would greatly appreciate that.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 1/4:

James Lin is an IP litigator.  He started at Fenwick & West and moved to Orrick where he met Zheng Liu, Matt Poppe and Mike Heafey.  

James left Orrick with other partners who wanted to represent patent trolls.  But the firm they went to was unable to handle antitrust work James obtained from Acer (his main client).  James left to start his own firm and grew it to 15+ attorneys.  When the Acer cases settled, the firm shrank to its current four partners.  James does not believe his current firm is a good fit any longer.  He continues to represent Acer (he projects $1M in business) and he also has other clients including a semiconductor company and an oil & gas company whose GC is James' brother.  The oil & gas company will have full service needs and James is poise to get all of the work.

James was soft spoken and he revealed that he had been out of work for 3.5 years because of a medical issue.  He has been back full time for the past six months and he said his practice is booming.

I think James could be a good fit with the firm, although I'm a bit concerned as to how he has been able to build a book that quickly after that long of a layoff.  We will need to carefully review his LPQ.

James said he has other offers (I know he had been speaking with FisherBroyles) and wants to move in February '24.

Rimon Initial Interview: Chandri Navarro has been a Customs and Trade partner in the D.C. office of Hogan Lovells for 20 years. Title: Partner
Private Management Notes: Need to inquire about telecom clients for potential conflicts with the entertainment group.
Tell us a little about your clients:
*ASK ABOUT TELECOM CLIENTS*
State of Idaho
What kind of work do you cross-service t: Employee Benefits & Executive Comp;Employment Law;Real Estate;Tax
What about Rimon is Particularly Excitin: Ability to work remotely;Collaboration model;Flexibility in billing;Lack of Bureaucracy
Closing reason details: Stated Rimon model would not work well with his practise
Interest in Rimon - Long Form: Jeff is just started the interview process but has already made the decision to move. He is not interested in BigLaw as he believes it will net more of the same.
Cross-Service -Long Form: Telecom; Environmental
Associate Work - Long Form: Jeff services most of his own work but gives about 200 hours a year to associates.
Office Space - Long Form: Jeff has been working remotely for last 3 years and would like to continue to do so. He would occasionally like to go into an office for face time or collaboration and would also use of conference room for occasional client meetings.
Rimon Initial Interview:
Jeff Cohen is a partner in the Washington, D.C. office of K&L Gates where he has practiced since 2015.  Prior to joining K&L, he was a partner with Troutman Pepper.

Jeff has a transactional practice that focuses on the development and financing of energy and infrastructure projects, with an emphasis on renewable energy project development.  His areas of expertise include solar, wind, geothermal, hydrogen, LNG, hydroelectric, biodiesel, and fossil fuels.   This solidly makes up about 80% of his client work.  Other work is a combination of construction, mining, P3, basic corporate transactions and a small niche of contract review for telecom companies.  Jeff's current billing rates are $1050/hr and $1200/hr which he wants to lower.  He does some work for his firm's institutional clients and other colleagues, but the bulk of his book is made up of clients that he has originated and self-services.  He expects almost all of his clients to follow him.

One of the reasons Jeff joined K&L was the collaborative atmosphere. Over the last two years, there has been a steady trickle of partner departures from the firm and his practice group including two practice group leaders and several rainmakers.  It has left him feeling like a lone wolf.  There were promises to rebuild, but that hasn't happened. In addition, Jeff has grown weary of the constant BigLaw bureaucracy and hoop-jumping. He has even experienced clients pulling matters because of the difficulty and time delay (over 2 weeks) to get new matters opened at his firm. 

Jeff was very pleasant to speak with and seems to be interested in making this move for all the right reasons. His energy practice would be a great addition and his desire for community and collaboration is also a good fit. Hopefully, he would be self-sufficient enough while we grow this practice area.
Porting Personnel Notes: None at this time.

Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
https://www.tocounsel.com/
45 attorneys

Gary couldn't confirm Harvey Oringher's reason for direct exit, but guessed it was a buy-out and a strategic decision to keep him on as Of Counsel. 

As a further clarification for the greater team, the two lead partners here take home appx. $7-8mm/annum combined. So while we'll certainly want to see their financials to understand their net and who gets paid what (including the rest of their attorneys), this potentially puts the appx. acquisition comp package from other firms at $15mm (i.e. assuming $24mm, which is 3 years of guaranteed comp for the two lead partners, less the $9mm AR balance). I can't directly confirm this $15mm number with Gary just yet as he hasn't heard hard numbers from the firms at the table but that's also his best guess based on napkin math and conversations with TO. FWIW, I'd be surprised if the numbers were different by any significant magnitude, and would be surprised if any upfront money was included in any other offer.
https://www.tocounsel.com/
45 attorneys
Mr. Oringher is not an employee of Theodora Oringher. As Of Counsel to the Firm, he is an independent attorney with a separate law practice that handles matters and clients having no affiliation with the firm, who also works on certain specific matters for the firm on a contract and case by case basis. His work is not affiliated with TO unless the client has a current written engagement letter with our firm.
Private Management Notes:
Notes from Rachel Braun:
We will really have to think about how to structure this, because unlike traditional firms that are buying that entire book of business and then paying a direct comp in return over a finite period, we are only “buying” 30% of books of business with the rest going to the attorneys. So perhaps if we do a more law firm traditional buyout here, we need to think about granting guaranteed comp for the top rainmakers instead of our normal "eat what you kill" approach.

They are talking to other more traditional firms.  ~40 FTE (no info on attorney vs staff breakdown), $25-30mm gross revenue, 50-65% of revenue generated by the only 2 equity partners: Todd Theodora and Kevin Dorse. 

Notable, per TJ: 2022 annualized run rate of $34-35mm, just under $800k revenue per attorney, and $9mm in open AR.

This call centered around the flexibility of what a potential offer would look like, which TO wanted to know before TO spent the time to engage. For example, in the other firms TO is talking to (bottom Amlaw 100 and also Amlaw 200), the firms are asking as a non-negotiable for all $9mm in open AR to be included in the transaction as a way to fund the transaction. While that's certainly a possibility for TO, our ability to be creative in structuring here in non-standard ways will be key, whether that's an upfront payment, leaving the AR out of the transaction, etc. I told Gary that we can certainly be creative in coming up with the best structure since everything is on the table for us. FWIW, most firms are likely to give them a 2-3 year guarantee on comp in exchange for the merger and the AR.

Title: Partner
Needs Office?: No, prefer working from home or client's office

Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 1/24:

Zack is personable and I get the impression that he is very good at business development.  He has a transactional/regulatory background and after a few years in a small firm, he landed at Akerman where he developed a national cannabis practice.   He built this practice to over $1mm and then accepted an offer to go in-house to act as GC for one of the largest cannabis companies (Tru Leaf).  

Tru Leaf was a short-term job, and when it ended two years ago Zach returned to Akerman, where he again built his practice to over $1mm.  Sensing a downturn in the cannabis market, Zack began to approach banks and insurance companies that do work with cannabis operators, ensuring that his practice could continue to thrive.  He also approached one of Akerman's antitrust partners and developed an expertise in Hart Scott Rodino to supplement his practice (and to get much higher rates).  When that partner left the firm, Zack became the go-to attorney for HSR work at the firm.

Zack is very interested in business development and sets goals for himself in terms of becoming a thought leader.  He speaks at several conferences per year and is one of the most quoted Akerman lawyers in the press.

Rates $700 for Cannabis work.  $900+ for HSR work.  He does not need an office and says he is fairly self-sufficient, needing little associate or paralegal assistance on his matters.

Zack also has generated a lot of business for others at Akerman (which is part of his book).  Practice areas include corporate, tax, IP, litigation, real estate, securities and others.

Zack is considering leaving Akerman because they are not as interested in promoting his practice and also because he feels that while he has generated a lot of work for partners in other practice areas, there has been little to no reciprocation.

I think Zack would be an excellent addition to Rimon.

Ed 8/28:

I really enjoyed speaking with Michael.  He was in public service from '06-18 representing pension funds in California (GC4, San Bernadino Cty) and managing the fund's assets.  He moved to Foley (they had been his outside counsel) as he had been targeted by partner Tom Hickey to take over his practice as he was retiring.

Michael has his own practice and at the beginning of '23 Tom retired and Michael assumed those clients as well (mostly pension funds and institutional investors).  Total book is $2.5M and fully portable (Foley has no other partner who can handle this work).  Additionally, 20-25% of Michael's practice is fielding fund and public sector questions from his partners (this is not portable, but he would be a great resource at Rimon).

Michael expressed a strong interest in representing his clients above all else.  He said comp is far less important to him ("I could happily go back to the public sector").  He is exploring a move because his public sector clients cannot afford his ever-climbing rate ($850).

The biggest issue with a move to Rimon is whether we could provide him the leverage he needs to continue to represent his clients at the highest levels.  Currently, he uses about 5-6 associates, none full-time, making up about 2.5 FTEs.

If we can make sure Michael could continue to represent his clients at the highest level, I am 100% in favor of having him join us.

This is a top-notch IP group.   Bob Whitman (electrical) and Mark Raskin (medical devices/life sciences) have built a team (one junior partner, two counsel and a senior paralegal) who have practiced together for several years across a couple of firms.

Their current firm is China-based, have recently closed their EU and Middle Eastern offices and is providing no support to the NY office.  The firm is also not transparent whatsoever. 

The group has at least a $5M fully portable book and they feel as though they have hit a ceiling. They want to build to at least $10M.  They bill their clients hourly, hourly with a success fee, contingent, and flat.  

Bob and Mark like that Rimon has an established IP group and is a full-service firm that is transparent and will allow them autonomy.

They do not need an office (shared meeting rooms are fine) and do not need much in support at present (although that could change as they continue to grow).  And their clients spin off work in other practice areas (corporate, tax, employment, other IP) and they would like to capture those dollars on Rimon's internal marketplace.

Mark and Bob want to move ASAP and are speaking with other firms.  I think they would make a fantastic addition to Rimon, and we should pursue this opportunity with vigor.
Secondary Practice Group: Bob - electrical engineering/tech; Mark - life sciences.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 1/25:

Matt Grant is a litigator in St. Louis who has spent the majority of  his career at Husch Blackwell.  He recently left the firm of rate presssure and internal politics and is looking to immediately join a new firm (currently, he is working as counsel in an IP firm run by a friend who knows the situation is temporary).  Matt said he is speaking with a few AmLaw firms as well and wants to move by early March '24.

Matt's practice involves agricultural and crop seed litigation, along with some toxic tort work.  He has one main client (approximately $500k of his $750-900k book) - Bayer Montsanto, whose US headquarters is in St. Louis.  He is not servicing that client while he is in between firms but "parked" the client with an attorney he trusts.  Matt's main contact at Bayer Monsanto has assured him the work will go right back to him as soon as he joins a new firm.  However, the client will want to see Matt's proposed "team," which, at least on paper, should include two associates and one paralegal.  Matt emphasized that this work ultimately could be done by others at Rimon and that the team he proposes will only be for the client to approve continuing to provide Matt with the work.

The client will like that Rimon has a St. Louis office but Matt likes to work remotely.  He does not usually use much paralegal time and uses minimal legal assistant support.

He has cross sold bankruptcy and commercial finance/loan work (which is specific to the AG industry).  The bankruptcy work will come to whatever firm he joins, he is less certain about the loan work.

I found Matt to be friendly and knowledgeable and he appears to be a good business generator.  We should continue to pursue this candidate.
