Rimon Initial Interview:
Sean Byrne 11/20:

Here are my notes from my ~45 min call with Christine and my review of her resume and law school transcript (resume re-attached for reference):

More mechanical notes, but someone perhaps worth having a follow-up meeting with Nicole or Geoff. She provided a plausible reason for reach move and represented to me that none of them were her being asked to leave. Moves were: wanted to move from NY to FL, wanted more sophisticated work, hated working with a particular partner, ended up working for just one client, and now because she doesn’t feel well integrated in her team as a remote worker.

She says that at DLA she largely runs most of the fundraising projects on which she works – initial setup and docs, LPA and side letter negotiations and revisions, running closings with junior associates and paralegals, etc. She’d like to be involved in group building, such as helping organize and put on trainings.

Says she’d prefer (at least initially) a salaried setup as opposed to an hourly one, in part because she’s looking to build a new house.

Law school:
-	Ranked #1 in her class
-	Federal income tax (A), state and local tax (A), corporate tax (A), international tax (A), taxation of M&A seminar (A), federal tax clinic (Pass)
Ropes in NYC:
-	17 months (plus summer associate)
-	Mainly mutual fund work
-	Left because wanted to move home to Florida and Ropes had no FL office and didn’t allow remote
Holland & Knight in FL:
-	11 months
-	Mainly mutual fund work
-	Left because they didn’t have much of a funds practice
Kirkland in TX:
-	30 months

Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 1/17:

Dan Boyce is the quintessential trial lawyer.  He has been practicing for almost 40 years in the Raleigh area and has worked on some of the most major cases in North Carolina.  His father was a legendary trial lawyer as well.  He worked with his father, then was an AUSA, then went back to private practice ending up at his current firm.  The firm recently merged and he is not happy with management, which prompted him accepting a call from a recruiter.

Dan works with his 20-year paralegal Brenna, who would join as well.  They do not need an office.  Associate help would be nice, and he said he could keep 1/2 of an associate busy, but not a definite necessity at this time.  Dan does generate work outside of litigation due to his deep roots in the Raleigh area, including tax, employment, corporate, IP, etc.  Rates are $550-575.

Dan did not quantify his book and, unlike his recruiter, said it is NOT $1M.  He said he does not want to work 1500-1900 hours/year anymore.   He will put together numbers to determine his anticipated portable book and will revert.

I liked Dan a lot but whether he is a good fit for Rimon is an open question, depending on his book.

Title: Partner
Closing Reason: Chose to stay at current firm
Tell us a little about your clients: Venture funds, start-ups, a large cannabis company.
What about Rimon is Particularly Excitin: Compensation Structure;Lack of Bureaucracy;Lifestyle;Opportunity to be on cutting edge
Rimon Initial Interview:
Call with Ed 10/3

Jon is a superstar.  He is 41 and graduated law school in 2011 (joint MBA/JD Northwestern).  He started his career at Sullivan & Cromwell in their M&A group.  After a couple of years, he realized he most enjoyed VC/emerging company work and moved to Goodwin in CA.  Over time, he realized that he enjoyed both practicing law and the business side as well.

He left Goodwin and started his own firm and also a venture fund, teaming up with another individual and raised $75mm, and worked mostly with Israeli start-ups.  He partnered with the Silverstein family that owns NY's World Trade Center and had a floor in that building.

In 2019, he had two associates and an admin and his legal book was around $750k.

One of his clients was in the cannabis space,  and he eventually joined that company, becoming CEO and Chairman of the Board.  The firm merged and now has a several hundred million dollar valuation.  As he throttled back on legal work he merged with another small firm run by a friend.

Jon now wants to plunge back fulltime into practicing law but he does not enjoy running a firm.  His book is around $500k, but this is clearly a brilliant, hardworking guy who is the epitome of entrepreneurial.  I highly recommend continuing the process with Jon.

Ed 12/7:

Mario is a Florida barred tax attorney.  He has $400k in originated business that consists of wealthy individuals and families and international businesses.  60% of his work is international corporate and 40% is estate planning (he does some work on CIFIUS matters as well). 

Mario has a tax background (he started at Deloitte) and has been in DC for 16 years because his wife wants to be here and not in Florida. Most of his work is Florida and South American based.  He knows and works with Rodrigo Cottin.

Mario was not necessarily looking to switch firms but his firm "is at an inflection point."  Whiteford has about the same number of lawyers as Rimon and they are aging out and the senior partners are not productive.  This has to change but no one in management is doing anything about it.

I have a couple of concerns about this one. First, Mario's book is under our minimum threshold.  This would be fine for a servicing tax partner, but we would need that only if Roy Gillig were fully engaged (I understand he is not at present).

Second, Mario volunteered that his current comp is $330,000, which is over 80% of his $400,000 book (as of today he has a $300,000 handle and $290,000 in the door - he is working on end-of-year collections).

Mario's "mentor" at Whiteford named Liz Atkinson is a tax controversy partner who also may be interested in Rimon. Mario said Liz' book is approximately $500,00.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 10/26:

Arthur brings expertise in municipal, state, and federal policy and regulatory issues, particularly focused on national and state broadband funding initiatives.  He works with a Senior Policy Advisor who would come with him.   they also may bring an assistant who is just out of college.  They are otherwise fairly self-sufficient.  Arthur said that the work is more policy oriented than legal.

Arthur told me that they are happy at their current firm, which is one of the best telecom firms in the country (and they have a $2M book (he guessed about $1.5 was portable)).  However, they are repeatedly running into conflicts and they want to see if there is another firm that would alleviate that problem.  This is particularly necessary now, as in 2024 the government is going to distribute $42B for broadband and Arthur wants to be able to pitch to small to midsized clients that he can help them receive some of those funds.  He will have a problem doing so because of conflicts with larger utility-sized firm clients.  

Arthur also mentioned more than once that perhaps existing Rimon clients could benefit from Arthur's team helping them potentially receive some of the funds mentioned above.

Arthur did say he would be nervous about coming to a firm with no salary/draw and that he would have to speak with his colleague about whether to continue the process.

I think this could be an intriguing match for Rimon. If Arthur wants to move forward, I would suggest that we continue to pursue the opportunity.

There have been 3-4 instances of substantial fraudulent billings to clients which do not set well with him (he personally discovered one and brought it to management's attention and did not feel it was handled properly). He also senses a lack of support. While he generally likes the people at his firm, he is ready to explore other options.

Rimon Initial Interview: Michael McClintock has been with the Oklahoma City office of the 175-attorney firm of McAfee & Taft for over 25 years.  The firm is well known in its market. Prior to joining his current firm, Michael served as a federal judicial clerk for the 10th Circuit. As a litigator, he has a broad practice which includes high net worth individuals, trust and probate litigation, commercial arbitration, family disputes, LLC matters, patent trademark and copyright lawsuits, securities, and oil and gas, M&A (and construction litigation to a smaller degree). Michael generates about $1.7mm in revenue annually and keeps an associate and service partner busy (supplying about 80% of their work). Michael bills 1700-1900 hours most years, and approx. 2200-2300 when there is a large trial. Current ates are 450/550/600.  Michael enjoys a variety of litigation and is well known within the state as a go-to AV rated attorney for high-profile cases. His military academy and active-duty experience give him an engineering background that has aided him in successfully handling patent infringement cases, from Markman through trial with several cases in CA. In addition, he has done several international arbitrations over Argentinian oil and gas reserves as well as TCE water migration cases. Michael also acts as an outside GC for some of his clients. Changes in management and the predominant perception of the firm as transactional make it difficult for his upward mobility, and it has caused him to consider looking at other firms. He has some concerns about handling filings outside of a hub. Michael is quick-witted and engaging (a great storyteller) with sophisticated experience. He would be a great addition to the firm.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 11/13:

Ben Keller is a senior T&E lawyer who is tired of bureaucracy, is not getting enough help, wants a national platform, and is intrigued by Rimon's model.  He has a unique practice where he often operates as "transition counsel" for family and other businesses (management succession).  He has contacts all over the US and wants to expand his practice to have a national presence.

He does like his current firm but says they are not national and is "20 years behind in everything" including effective cross selling.  His clients spin off work in a variety of practice disciplines (tax, employment, litigation, Corporate (M&A) and he would like to be able to capture that work.  

His book has been as high as $3.5M at his old firm (he helped found and managed Lathrop’s St Louis office) but it is now $1.5-2M because he does not have enough help on his matters.  He does not want to do the nuts-and-bolts work and would rather serve as a senior mentor and hand off work to other partners/associates.

Ben would like to bring a team with him, which would include former Rimon candidate Robin Ragland (we made her an offer in early '22 and she very reluctantly decided to join another firm - apparently that has not worked out), and 1-2 associates.  He also has a corporate paralegal and an assistant.

What about Rimon is Particularly Excitin: Collaboration model;Compensation Structure;Flexibility in billing;Lack of Bureaucracy;People in the firm
Closing reason details: Going in a different direction
Cross-Service -Long Form: A large amount of Mark's book is cross-selling.  Mark is the "relationship partner" on many of his matters.
Admin Support -Long Form: Minimal
Associate Work - Long Form: 1/2 corp. assoc. time, 1/2 lit. assoc. time.
Office Space - Long Form: Access to an office would be great but he does not need one day-to-day
Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 8/31:

Mark, who is friends with John Mussman, is a very affable guy and a pleasure to speak with. He is a rainmaker who has done a mix of corporate and litigation over the years but now does strictly corporate work.  He calls himself a "trusted advisor" and gets referrals for work internationally (US, Zurich, London, Malaysia etc.) in numerous practice areas (corporate, L&E, IP, litigation, real estate).  His clients include banks, corporations, family offices, NBA and NFL players and more.  In the last 18 months, Mark has worked with 67 partners, associates and paralegals. 

This year, Mark's collections will be around $2.1M and he is grossly undercompensated (seriously).

One concern that I explored is that Mark has moved several times in recent years.  He had his own firm for years but sold it in 2012 to a Chicago firm and was on a one-year contract.  One of his main clients at that time was BofA, who had most of its work done by Duane Morris.  His contact at BofA convinced Mark to move there.  Mark thought DM was a great firm, but they raised his rates, eventually to $900/hour and a majority of his clients balked.  So, after four years at DM, Mark went with five of his colleagues to Thompson Coburn, which, in Mark's words, was "a total train wreck."  Mark and his colleagues were never fully integrated into the firm and were actively excluded by the existing Chicago partners.

So, 18 months after joining TC, Mark went to Johnson & Bell for three years.  He ran that firm's corporate practice and doubled his book.  The rates were reasonable.  Mark was not looking to leave but he know a lot of lawyers at his now-current firm (Hinshaw) and they convinced him to move there.  At Hinshaw, Mark doubled his book again. The problem is that he is not getting compensated in any way close to what he should be given his originations/collections.  Thus, Mark is considering another move, this time to Rimon (John Mussman has occasionally suggested that Mark join us).

Mark utilizes 1/2 of a FT Corp. associate and 1/2 time of a litigation associate but would of course consider working with partners or paralegals.

Rates: $525-$825
**corporate - $500-$600
**regulatory - $800

I like Mark a lot.  He has made several recent moves but his explanation for them track with me.  I recommend we continue the process.

Status: E.0 Ready to Join / Offer Made
Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 2/5 (had previous call with her back in July '23):

Cristina Cardenas was a Reed Smith partner and was introduced to us at the end of July ‘23 with Eduardo De la Pena. They have worked together for 15 years.  At that time their combined book was around $1.5mm.  Rate pressure and conflicts were hurting their practice at Reed Smith, plus the senior partner with whom they worked was retiring at the end of ’23.   I very much enjoyed meeting with them and hoped we could land them both.

As the months went by, they became unresponsive.  Of course, Eduardo resurfaced and is now slated to join us at the beginning of April (with a projected book around $650-700k).  During the past six months, Cristina’s situation changed.  Her father became ill and she had to take a big step back from her practice to help with the family horse business.  Also, Cristina was repeatedly running into roadblocks to being named arbitrator on matters (actual conflicts, business conflicts and needing the Chairman’s approval to be named an arbitrator).  Reed Smith asked her to leave the firm at the end of the year.

Since that time, Cristina has completed what she needed to do for her family’s business and has been rebuilding her practice on her own.  She submitted an LPQ which reflects that her book is not yet close to our $650k minimal requirement.  But Cristina has a strong conviction that she will be able to rebuild in short order and would love to continue to work with Eduardo here at Rimon.  Adding Ricardo Ampudia is a great help too.

Bottom line, I think we should proceed with Cristina despite her numbers not being where we usually would want them.

 Steven also represents clients in complex civil litigation and his rates range between $600-900 on those matters.

Steven said that only 6-7 of his attorneys are capable of doing more than foreclosure work, which would hamper the ability to acquire the firm.  May be a Nova play.

Title: Partner
Closing Reason: Chose to stay at current firm
Private Management Notes:
Answer to question about taking equity in client's business as payment (from TJ):

W/r/t equity in clients, and for mainly conflicts reasons, the firm slightly altered its policy on taking equity in clients in late Q3 last year. In short, the firm does not want to take equity in clients moving forward, but if a partner wants to do so, the firm has no issue with it. As a result, we're left with two effective options: 1) 70% of the legal fees can be paid in equity (to the attorney, personally) with 30% being paid in cash (to the firm), or 2) 100% of the legal fees can be paid in equity (to the attorney personally), but the firm would request that the equivalent 30% in cash be deducted from the attorney's ARA. 

Option 1 is certainly cleaner, but perhaps not always preferable from a client perspective. Option 2 results in the attorney and the firm aligning on a mechanism and timing to accomplish that (for example, taking into account how long the representation is expected to last, making sure that external billing rate and hours are tracked, etc). We're typically open to number of months post termination of the representation to effectuate this (typically 3 months or so), or to align as we go along during the representation.
Tell us a little about your clients: His clients are a mix of major U.S. and international producers (Latin America, Asia), midstream companies, independent commodity trading houses/markets, start-ups and private equity. About 65% of his work is focused on M&A (commercial agreements, fractional agreements, energy transition and infrastructure). Another 20-25% is focused on trading houses, buying assets and private equity, and the remaining is  a mix of start-ups and LNG project developers (currently 3 projects and will grow). SK Gas, Atrium and Sumitomo mentioned. Gabe's current rate at Akin Gump is $1450. Gabes says 70-80% of his clients would port.

Rimon Initial Interview: Gabe Procaccini has been an attorney with Akin Gump for a little over 16 years and a partner there for 10 years. He has a broad energy practice and primarily represents public traded companies that produce oil and gas. He has experience in virtually every type of energy related work (with the exception of solar) and has particular expertise with midstream transactions. His clients are a mix of major U.S. and international producers (Latin America, Asia), midstream companies, independent commodity trading houses/markets, start-ups and private equity. About 65% of his work is focused on M&A (commercial agreements, fractional agreements, energy transition and infrastructure). Another 20-25% is focused on trading houses, buying assets and private equity, and the remaining is  a mix of start-ups and LNG project developers (currently 3 projects and will grow). Gabe typically refers tax and regulatory work. Gabe is also a frequent speaker on energy issues.  Gabe's current billing rate at Akin Gump is $1450. Gabe is looking for the right platform where he has a more flexible rate structure, can "get out of the black box system",  and can continue to build his client base in a supportive environment. Gabe is personable, entrepreneurial, client-focused and would be a good fit for Rimon.

Title: Principal
Private Management Notes:
ESW 1/14/22 (updated 12/4/23)

Since 2011, Alan has moved around a lot.  He has been at five firms since the firm he was at for 10 years imploded.  From there, he moved to  Schiff Hardin but that firm soon forced him give up his largest client and he left after 1.5 years.  He then went to a regional NY firm and realized the fit was not appropriate and left after 1.5 years.

Alan then opened his own firm in 2014.  But in 2017 he got divorced and needed more stability, so he joined "CKR."  That firm disbanded in 2019, which is why he moved to his current firm.

Alan wants to leave his current firm because he believes he receives no benefit from it.  He thinks Rimon would be the perfect fit.  All of his clients are portable.

In '22 Alan chose to go to Offit Kurman instead of Rimon.  If he joins Rimon now that will be seven firms since 2011.  His reason for reconsidering his Offit choice make sense (level of sophistication of practice) but the moves all combined continue to give me pause.

Greg Weston is a partner in the New York office of Winston & Strawn where he has practiced since 2015. Prior to joining, he worked at Pillsbury. In the past, Greg's practice focused on structured finance work around real estate and asset classes, including P3 and other infrastructure projects. His practice is now more focused on investment funds where he represents sponsors of real estate, private equity and debt funds regarding fund formation, capital raising, securities, regulatory, compliance, and other transactional work. 

Greg works with both entrepreneurs and large institutional investors. Beyond his investment management and fund formation expertise, Greg regularly originates M&A, real estate and finance transactions. He has consistently generated a solid book ($1mm+) of loyal clients and acts as outside GC for some. He believes all of his clients will follow him. Greg's most active clients are middle market and the continued rate hikes at his firm (he is currently at $1400/hr) have become a challenge for some of his emerging clients. Greg enjoys cross-selling work and collaborating with other attorneys (Litigation, IP, real estate), but has also run into conflicts in bringing in new business.

 DEI is very important to Greg, and he is very involved at his firm. He hopes he can have similar involvement in DEI should he join Rimon. Greg is a personable individual with solid business goals and would be a great fit at Rimon.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Maren Calvert has been a partner in the Vancouver, WA office of Schwabe, Williamson & Wyatt for the last two years. Her practice focuses on land use and commercial real estate, and she is also developing a mediation practice.  Her clients are primarily land use developers in Southwest Washington and Oregon where she services them in negotiating permits, ‎land use applications, development agreements, inter-‎governmental and P3 agreements as well as litigation, land use disputes, administrative hearings and appeals.  

Maren started out as a commercial litigator in California and then Hawaii (admitted, but inactive).  During that time, she was often pulled into large bankruptcy cases to work on their real estate disputes and condominium law. In 2011, she was called back to active duty and worked on legislative affairs and administrative law issues at the Pentagon and Capitol Hill. Maren retired from the Air Force in 2016 and returned to private practice in the Pacific Northwest focusing on land use law and related administrative procedures.

Maren and her partner Steve Horenstein transitioned to Schwabe together from his firm, Horenstein Law Group in Vancouver, and would like to make the next move together with their associate (Josaundra), who is a second-year associate with 20+ years' experience as a paralegal. Steve is more senior and will likely practice another five to seven years and transition his clients to Maren. Steve's practice focuses on business planning, transactions, and finance; commercial real estate transactions, leasing, and finance; land use and environmental permitting; and government relations, advocacy, and public policy.  Maren and Steve have over a $2mm book together.  

When the group came to Schwabe certain promises were made that have not materialized, and they don't believe the firm has the same vision as when they joined. They are looking for a firm that if willing to look at the practice of law creatively and that values collegiality and collaboration. Maren is also passionate about mentoring younger attorneys. 

Maren was very interesting and delightful to speak with. If her partner is on board and the financials work, they would be a nice addition to our real estate practice and add a deeper bench in the area of land use.
Porting Personnel Notes: Will come over with Steve Horenstein, Partner and Josaundra Hansen, Associate. Together they have a $2mm book. Expect they will have a pooling agreement.

Marlon Primes is an equity partner in the Cleveland office of Brennan Manna and Diamond, and the Co-Chair of its Business and Tort Litigation practice. Prior to joining BMD, Marlon was an assistant U.S. attorney for the Northern District of Ohio for close to 30 years and is skilled in many areas of litigation. 

Marlon's current practice is very diverse and includes employment litigation (40%), false claims act litigation, real estate litigation, securities litigation, and internal investigations. His clients include a large Fortune 300 energy client (he serves as outside GC), national franchises, healthcare providers, the City of Cleveland and other government entities. 

Marlon has seen a lot of turn-over in his firm and he has begun to doubt the security of his firm's future. As his practice has grown with national clients, Marlon feels he can both grow his clientele and better service them on a broader platform and capitalize on his national and state contacts. He expects all of his clients to follow him.

Marlon is affable, has a "soft touch", is knowledgeable in various areas of litigation and excited about collaboration opportunities. Marlon is involved in affinity bar organizations, holding leadership positions at a local and national level and a frequent conference speaker. In addition, he is an adjunct professor at the University of Akron teaching contracts and real estate transactions.  He would be a great addition to our litigation team.

From recruit emails 7/31-8/6/19:
Updated Information:
Some updates, as I had an insurance client pay up this month.
    YTD Working collections:  $230,681 (annualized $395,453)
    YTD Originating collections: $378,201 (annualized $648,345)
    A/R (My working time only):  $415,599
    A/R (My originating - all time): $576,021
 
My A/R is, again, the corporate client PurFi Global, who has not yet closed, but whom I am working on to close at this point in time.
 
Dallas Office:
My current firm’s Dallas office is small, though we do have several talented lawyers there.  The firm has three full-time lawyers in that office, another who is moving to Tulsa and one other lawyer who is essentially part-time in hours worked.  Although my firm does want to grow the office there (main priority for growth are the office HQ in Tulsa and OKC), it is extremely hesitant to take the risk of lateral expansion, which to me is frustrating, because I expressed a desire to be down there, especially when I first came back on board at C&W in April 2017.  Before coming on board in 2017, I was told Dallas would be an option if I would agree to a formula and essentially an eat-what-you-kill arrangement.  I couldn’t do so at the time, coming from the firm I had been at which was cash-poor - I needed a stable (and better) salary at the time.  If I broached the subject again today (which I haven’t brought it back up), I’m not sure what the answer would be - although I know the preference would be to have me in the Tulsa (HQ) office.

It was expressed to me by the firm’s President (a good friend of mine) that the focus of the firm is to shore-up its main offices:  Tulsa and Oklahoma City.  It is essentially an Oklahoma-based firm; though I believe the better business is located in Texas.  And I can fully practice law and represent my Oklahoma-based clients wherever my office is, including in Dallas.
Closing Reason: Chose to stay at current firm

Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 4/12:

Noah started his career in the Justice Department and was there for seven years.  In 2016 he moved to Baker Botts for two years and then became an AUSA in the Western District of Texas.  He would have stayed there but in 2020 Justice wanted him to move to DC for a year and he was about to have his fifth child.  He moved to DLA as a Counsel so he could stay in Dallas.

DLA promised that Noah would have plenty of work but when he arrived there was almost none.  So, he marketed himself extensively within the firm and over time became the go-to litigator for the firm's Investment Management Group.  Noah is now a co-leader for the firm's Private Fund Disputes practice, and he focuses on institutional investors, with an emphasis on public investment systems, sovereign wealth funds, and development finance institutions, as well as financial services companies of all types.

Noah's efforts have allowed him to quickly grow his book of business with very little help from his firm.  The firm does not help him market his practice (which he says he definitely wants at his new firm) and he is dramatically undercompensated considering he has managed to build a $2-3mm book over the last couple of years.  Most of this work will be portable. 

Rates are currently $1,100.  He does not need an office, uses about 700-1000 hours of associate time and sporadically needs paralegal help.

I found Noah to be a bit intense and very confident in his abilities.  If our IM group could utilize his expertise, Noah could be a strong asset.  I recommend we pursue his candidacy.

Title: Partner
Closed Recruit Name: Jeff Blank (Garcia Rainey Blank & Bowerbank LLP)
Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes:
next steps per Juan 8/15/22:
Norma Garcia  Manny Medrano, Brian Hafter
Tabitha Rainey  David Devernoe, Bertha Cortes
Jeff Blank  Paul Loving, Matt Pace
John Bowerbank  Craig Granet, David Choi (has significant construction defense litigation experience)
Jimmy Chen  Jim Chapman, Mark C. Lee
***

Private Management Notes 3
I just had breakfast with Norma Garcia and their group is very much in play.  Their main hesitations are (i) losing their autonomy and sense of family (the 5 partners as a team) and (ii) their current overhead is around 15% so they’d be giving up double.  Notwithstanding, she is VERY intrigued and this may be the right moment to make a change this year.

As to (i) autonomy: I am going to introduce her to Jenn Duffy to discuss how the Santa Barbara team came over and that they have integrated very well while still keeping their sense of “local family”.  I think we can win them over on this score.

(ii) Overhead and profitability:  I told her that the key to overcome this fear is that she can make up the lost revenue on the internal market.  Moreover, Norma is very frustrated because she as lost some very high ticket litigation matters recently to larger firms.  She is concerned that the small profile of her current firm is going to keep her forever handling small potatoes matters for certain clients and she knows she is losing opportunity under the current circumstances.  We can solve this for her and she knows it.  In addition, our depth in real estate and cross-border planning could help her capture more work that they can’t currently handle.

She needs to convince her partners that the benefits of a Rimon move would outweigh what they perceive as leaving money on the table.  I could see the gears turning in her head.  We may need to proceed with an interim Global Alliance arrangement for them to get more comfortable but we can definitely close this one but it will take some continued nurturing on our part.  However, I could see bringing this on board and increasing their origination significantly under our platform.
Closing Reason: Chose to stay at current firm
Private Management Notes:
Note from Juan 8/12/22:
- Please refer as Norma Garcia, not Norma Guillen.
- Are you sure they need to give up their 401k?  Can’t they join (like I am) with their professional corporation as a contractor to Rimon?  In that scenario, all revenue (after the Rimon 30%) comes into their company, they pay their wages and maintain their existing retirement plans?  Or are we not allowing such a model any more?
- The answer to the above will inform the question of whether they need to “switch” accounting firms.  If they keep their existing entity, they will need separate accounting for that entity.

He also is not receiving as much comp as he feels he deserves.  

Book is always more than $1mm and at times has reached $2mm.  He is on pace for $1.6mm this year.  He also cross-sells in numerous practice areas (an additional $300-400k).  Rate is typically $665. I liked Anthony and believe he would be a strong addition to Rimon.

Rimon Initial Interview: Marci Lerner Miller is a Partner in the Litigation and Government Investigations, Privacy and Cybersecurity, and Education Practice Groups of Potomac's L.A. office.  She represents clients in matters involving data privacy, standardized testing, civil rights, disability rights, and accessibility. Most of her clients are in education (universities) and she also works with the ACLU, ADL, public interest groups, K-12 schools on student privacy and sits on the board of a few colleges. Title: Partner
Needs Office?: No, prefer working from home or client's office
Tell us a little about your clients: Dr. Koschmieder counsels domestic and foreign clients on intellectual property portfolio management and development, opinions and patent prosecution.  A large percentage of his clients are Saudi entities.

Office Space - Long Form: Whole team could be remote.
Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 12/19:

Stefan is a chemical patent prosecution partner and co-chair of the firm’s MENA (Middle East North Africa) area practice group.  He counsels domestic and foreign clients, most of his clients are Saudi entities. He has successfully prosecuted patents and defended industry-leading methods for recovering petroleum resources, petroleum exploration and development, and chemical process development, design and manufacturing. Additionally, he advises his clients on inventorship, chemical and business methods, patentability, validity and enforceability and represents them before the Patent Trial and Appeal Board (PTAB) and in disputes in district court litigation. He is also actively involved in establishing intellectual property programs and patent portfolios for clients based in the Middle East.

Stefan is looking outside of his current firm for the first time in 23 years because the firm is "unhealthy," and he is undercompensated while several senior partners are paid more and working far less.  

Current book is $4M.  Most is flat fee billing.  He mentioned that his clients often pay in a "lumpy" fashion, sometimes not paying in full for several months (mostly because the Saudi government has to approve payments outside of SA).  He is not concerned about this even on Rimon's model, although he would have to pay his staff in a timely fashion.

Stefan services about 10% of this work himself.  The bulk of the work is performed by his team of six patent agents ($150k/year each) and three paralegals.  He is unsure how many of his staff would follow if he were to join Rimon, but said it would be at least 50%. 

Stefan appears to be near the top of his profession.  I highly recommend pursuing his candidacy.
Porting Personnel Notes: Sefan would need six patent agents and three paralegals dedicated to his practice.  He is unsure how many of his current staff would join him if he were to move to Rimon (he said at least 50% for sure), so this is an issue we will need to solve for.

Patrick is a top international arbitration partner candidate who had been based in China but has moved to the LA area, both for family and client reasons (China's economy is down and Chinese entities are looking to invest outside of China, including in the US).  His book is between $3-4mm, and he represents a number of Chinese entities in front of arbitration bodies in numerous locations.  He also represents non-Chinese corporations and foreign governments.  He has a strong grasp of Chinese and UK law. 

Patrick is licensed in NY and attended Berkeley for his LLM, where he met Zheng several years ago (Zheng did not recall the meeting but that is likely because she was setting up a program for students and Patrick was one of many students).  He is sitting for the CA bar soon.  He also has a green card.

Zheng took the lead in discussing Rimon's China practice with Patrick and explained that our Shenzen office is not a law office (it is a consulting office) and that we likely would not be opening an office there.  Patrick utilizes up to four associates there at present and he indicated he would like to have one or two of them join him if he were to join Rimon.  This obviously could not work if Rimon is not willing to open an office there.

Another issue is that Patrick represents SOEs (state owned entities) and we are not inclined to do so (this could cause problems with existing Taiwanese clients for instance and also open us up to scrutiny from governmental agencies).

Patrick could be a strong addition to Rimon if he were willing to forego representing SOEs and could find US associates who can handle Chinese and other international arbitration matters, this could work.  If not, there would be too many obstacles.

Hector Chichoni is partner in the Miami office of Duane Morris where he practices U.S. and global immigration law. Hector's practice covers H-1Bs, H-2Bs, EB-5s, blanket L visas, work authorizations, 1-9 compliance and work site enforcement actions, immigration audits, and he also handles crossovers between immigration and export control matters. Hector also regularly refers tax, labor & employment, corporate, and intellectual property work.

The majority of Hector's work is self-originated and self-serviced.  He does not use associates and generally keeps two paralegals busy which he believes would join him should he make the move. Hector is frustrated with rate pressure at Duane Morris and believes that $790/hr is steep for clients. He prefers to use flat fees and Rimon's flexibility is attractive to him. 

Hector is admitted in TX and Utah and is fluent in Spanish, Portuguese, and French. Hector is very experienced, personable and would be a great addition to the firm.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 4/3/24:

Chris is a very friendly and outgoing commercial litigator (he also handles bankruptcy matters).  He lives in Ft. Lauderdale, and he splits his practice between Florida and Ohio/Kentucky where he lived previously.

He was first a Rimon candidate in May '20 when he was a partner in a small firm in Cincinnati.  Since that time, Chris has made several moves, all of which made sense to me as he described them. First, moved to Ft. Lauderdale and chose Dickinson Wright over Rimon, thinking he wanted to remain in a traditional firm.  But he did not like the size of the firm, preferring a smaller shop, so in May '22 he moved to Gray Robinson.  He liked that firm but was approached by Taylor English in April '23, where he had many connections.  By then, Chris, who had already explored a distributed model, was ready to try it.  He has been happy at TE, but he told me there are changes occurring at with the firm comp. structure which will negatively affect him.  Further, he cannot get the help he needs to maintain his practice - he is turning away work and working far too many hours (2500+) which is negatively affecting him personally.  Thus, he approached us to restart his candidacy.

In the past few years, Chris has built his practice to where he is on pace for over $800k this year.  He told me he does not need office space (although "it would be nice"), but he would want Rimon to consider opening a virtual office in Cincinnati and/or Lexington KY so he would have website visibility with his clients that are based in that region.  

Chris does need associate help on the ground in Florida so that he can reduce his hours and focus on additional BD and his personal life.  I told him that he would need to sponsor a Florida associate, which he understood.  He also contemplated hiring a legal assistant.

I liked Chris personally very much, which is consistent with the interviews he had with other Rimon partners in '20.  I recommend we continue the process with him.

The firm also has four staff members at the firm, including a FT para (12 years), legal secretary, admin/file person/receptionist.   Jeb would want to retain his associates and staff (although one attorney may retire)

They have an office leases in SF and Reno but do not need all of the space they currently have.  They would get rid of the SF space but he believes Reno is a growth area and one of the firm's anchor clients is located there.

Jeb said that they send a lot of work outside of their firm, including securities regulatory, restructuring and commercial litigation.  He would like to capture those dollars at a larger firm like Rimon.  Jeb also would like to stop having to run his own firm.

Title: Partner
Tell us a little about your clients: Italian fashion and luxury goods companies (NY), also some manufacturing (Chicago) and hospitality (Miami)
What kind of work do you cross-service t: Corporate;Employment Law;Intellectual Property;Immigration;International Tax;International Transactions;Real Estate
Cross-Service -Long Form: Nicola and Martin's Italian clients who want to do business in the US need help with contracts, joint ventures, corporate agreements, IP transactional work, immigration and customs.
Office Space - Long Form: They have an office they can use anytime and do not need any office space from Rimon.
Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 8/24:  Nicola is a lawyer's lawyer.  He was polished, interesting and clearly very good at what he does.  He is based in Rome and his "partner" Martin Guizzardi is based in Milan.   Nicola did spend 32 years in the US before moving back to Italy.

Nicola has been a partner with Bryan Cave for 15 years and has been affiliated with the firm’s Chicago office that entire time. He moved to Rome about 18 months ago and is working remotely from there. (Bryan Cave does not have any offices in Italy.)  Apparently, all billings are through the Chicago office, in U.S dollars. 

Martin has supported Nicola’s practice for many years, and he is a foreign contract partner for Bryan Cave, not an employee, thus he’s not on the firm's website. Although he worked in the U.S. for a while, Martin moved back to Italy during the pandemic and is currently working remotely from Milan. This works well for both Nicola and Martin because they are physically close to their Italian client base (and in the same time zone) but utilize many timekeepers within the U.S. for their inbound-to-U.S. practice.

Together, Nicola (the rainmaker) and Martin (whom Nicola is grooming to succeed him) have a practice representing over 100 Italian companies (mostly in the fashion and luxury goods industries, but also manufacturing and hospitality) who want to expand and do business in the US.  This practice generated between $3.5-3.8M in 2022.  On the right platform with no rate pressure, they believe they can exceed $6M.

Nicola and Martin also work with an Italian law firm and a CPA firm who currently provide them with referrals for US bound work.  In addition to the US work they do for their Italian clients, they want to pick up Italian work.  They would work with these firms, and hopefully have those firms join Rimon as well in a "second wave."  This would bring in another $5+M in business.

Nicola said they are looking to leave Bryan Cave because of unceasing rate pressure.  Nicola's Italian clients are balking at constant rate increases (his current rate is $1100, and Nicola said this is "unsustainable.") 

Because of the referrals between Nicola/Martin and the other firms Nicola suggests that perhaps they could join Rimon US and not open a separate Italian entity that could "compete" with those firms (before they all possibly join). This structure is to be discussed further but would be similar to what they have at Bryan Cave.

This is a very exciting partner team and I highly recommend pursuing.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Ralph Cuervo-Lorens is an equity partner in the Toronto, Canada office of McMillan, one of the largest Canadian law firms.  Ralph has practiced at McMillan since 2018 and was previously a partner at Blaney McMurtry and at Fraser Milner Casgrain (Dentons). Ralph is Co-Chair of McMillan's National Environmental Group and Co-Chair of its Latin America Initiative.

Ralph began his law career in litigation and his practice has evolved over the years to become over 50% focused on a wide range of environmental law including risk management, compliance, environmental permitting, impact-assessment, regulatory defense, internal investigations, health & safety, ESG/sustainability, and ADR. The majority of his clients are in the manufacturing, transportation, construction, mining, and commercial land development space. Another 15% of his practice is tax law including compliance, tax litigation, tax evasion, quasi white-collar (civil and criminal), and white-collar fraud.  In addition, Ralph also handles aboriginal/indigenous/tribunal law, commercial disputes, and government procurement on a smaller scale. Ralph's current billing rate is $1025/hr. CAD (approx. $745/hr. USD) which he hopes to reduce a bit. Ralph refers M&A, real estate and securities work.

Ralph is considering a move for multiple reasons:   his firm has a mandatory retirement age and no succession plan, promises to expand the firm's Latin America practice have not materialized, and a culture shift within the firm has created more bureaucracy.

Ralph expects that at least another partner and senior associate would join him. Rimon has had interest in opening in Toronto for some time and this may be a good opportunity.
Porting Personnel Notes: Bringing in this group would require a new physical office in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Ralph may bring into the discussion a junior partner and a senior associate from his current firm, as well as two senior partners from a different firm. ^Market analysis may be beneficial for advice on rate setting.^

Sol Wisenberg is a former AUSA who has developed a strong white-collar practice (including FTC and SEC investiations).  Sol was a member of Ken Starr's team during the Clinton/Lewinsky investigation.  He then went into private practice, joining Ross, Dixon & Bell before forming a two person firm with his wife.  Several years abo he joined Nelson Mullins.  He likes his current firm but feels that the comp system is unfair, and the firm has become too big to be collegial, not to mention the conflicts issues.

Sol is a Fox News contributor and has been a legal commentator on that channel for several years.  He told me he always keeps his answer legal (and told me that privately, while he is a lifelong Republican, he thinks the former President has "ruined" the country).

Aside from 2022, when a ponzi scheme case ran out of insurance money to late for him to withdraw causing him to only collect $400k, he consistently has averaged between $1-1.2M in originations year after year.  This year, Sol has collected $400k through the end of April.   

Most of Sol's work comes from referrals (and a lot of that because people have seen him on TV).

Sol said he would feel most comfortable joining Rimon when he brings in a case with a large retainer.  He is extremely motivated to move but has no set timeframe.

I liked Sol very much and think he could be a great addition to Rimon.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 7/8:

Gene is a Maryland based commercial litigator.  He has been in small firms in Montgomery County, MD (outside DC) and represents clients in civil matters.  He has worked in several smaller Maryland firms and between 2016-2022 ran his own solo practice.  The practice had 3-4 associates and 4-5 support staff.   

In 2022, his current firm (a small corporate transactional boutique) approached Gene to grow a litigation practice.  The firm promised Gene that it would have a lot of litigation work, very little of which materialized.  The firm has tried to cut some of his comp, even as he has brought in over $800k and he is now considering whether to reopen his own firm or join a larger platform.  He really wants to begin to transition his practice to push down work to younger attorneys.  If he were to join Rimon he would plan to bring two paras and an associate.  

Book is $750k-$1.1mm.  Rates are $450-685, and trending towards the higher number.  All work is portable.

I don't believe Gene's practice is sophisticated enough for Rimon.  Further, he seemed a bit gruff (saying negative things about his current firm in, shall we say, colorful language) and would pass on those bases.

Title: Member
Needs Office?: No, prefer working from home or client's office
Closing Reason: Chose to stay at current firm
Tell us a little about your clients: Financial institutions, fintech, corporate clients.
Closing reason details: doesn't think it is the right fit for his practice at this time
Interest in Rimon - Long Form: Does not collaborate much at current firm.  Likes Rimon's model.
Cross-Service -Long Form: Mostly in conjunction with M&A transactions.
Admin Support -Long Form: Minimal -- Joe said he is fairly self-sufficient
Associate Work - Long Form: Minimal.
Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 7/3:

Joe is an engaging financial institutions partner who advises his clients on a variety of corporate and regulatory matters including mergers & acquisitions, securitizations, strategic transactions, governance, international banking, payments, anti-money laundering and sanctions compliance, and private equity and venture capital investments.

Book is around $750,000.  Joe said that he is 100% confident that 80% of that is fully portable and the other 20% could be as well but he doesn't want to over promise.  His rate is $640 for corporate transactional work and $450-500 for regulatory work.  He is very self-sufficient and does not rely much on associates, paralegals or legal support staff.  He does not need office space.

Joe has moved around a lot in the past 10 years, but his reasons for each move seem logical.  In 2015 he went to Lock Lord from the Fed as a counsel but was there for less than 18 months because they misled him by telling him there would be bank regulatory work.  There was none.  So he moved to Schiff Hardin as a counsel, which did have the work.  He was there just over 18 months and would've stayed but the main bank client of the firm was hit with an enforcement action which halted all M&A deals. 

Faced with the prospect of having no work, Joe moved to Chapman & Cutler as a counsel.  Six months after he joined, the main banking partner and several associates left the firm.  Joe started doing corporate transactional work and the firm told him at his second review that they considered him a banking expert and that he was not going to be on a partnership track.

Faced with job uncertainty at Chapman, Joe left to join Howard & Howard as an equity partner (they had approached him).  Howard had a retiring partner and wanted Joe to join for succession planning.   Three years later there was a contentious CEO battle and Joe left for Dickenson along with the group with whom he had worked at Howard.  Thus, Joe has been working with the same group for over five years, across two firms.

Joe is interested in Rimon because while he very much likes the people at Dickinson, he feels as though he is siloed.  He would like the opportunity to work with more partners across more practice areas.

Joe is considering whether he is comfortable with Rimon's model.  I liked him and am satisfied with his reasons for moving around a lot.  If he is interested in continuing the process I recommend we do so.

Greg is a senior litigator who has practiced for 45 years.  For 42 years he was at Miller Canfield, a prominent Michigan firm.  He has had a book as large as $6mm at times but the last 4-5 years it has been closer to $1mm - all of which is fully portable.  His specialties include antitrust litigation, and he has also done a lot of entertainment litigation (talent side).  He is best friends with an attorney who is the former GC of both Ford Motor Co. and Coca Cola and his friend still regularly feeds him client work.

Greg likes his current firm but feels as though they want him to retire even though he loves practicing law and wants to continue doing so for the foreseeable future.  Additionally, there is almost no cross-selling at his current firm, and he would like to be at a firm where work flows to and from him.

Greg does not need an office.  He has an admin. assistant who has worked with him for more than 20 years who he would almost certainly want to bring with him.  He also has a longtime paralegal who he also might want to bring.  Finally, he is working with a non-partnership track attorney (clerk) who Greg says is very good and who he may or may not want to bring with him were he to join Rimon.

I liked Greg a lot. He is friendly and a "litigator's litigator."  He remains hungry and energetic, and I think he could be a great addition to Rimon.

The Martin/Dinner firm is part of the Dentons network.  Randy Martin and David Dinner are 50/50 equity shareholders.  They are not really looking to join Rimon or be acquired by Rimon, but rather they are looking for a PE buyout (multiples of earnings structured over time).  Martin and Dinner want to step back from management to focus on practicing law and other endeavors and are grooming one of their partners to become MP. 

They also said they want to double in size within five years.

Their expenses are high, particularly because to hire non-Caymanians, they have to pay for "work permits" that can run from a few thousand dollars to upwards of $40,000.  They also have had significant IT expenses in the past couple of years to move to a cloud-based system. 

NET PROFIT last year was only around $1.5-2M.
Tell us a little about your clients: Full service law firm representing high net worth individuals, hedge funds, family offices and others. They handle licensing, immigration, T&E, real estate, litigation, aviation and other matters.
Closing reason details: M&A candidates
Interest in Rimon - Long Form: See Private Notes
Admin Support -Long Form: The Martin Dinner firm has 14 support staff.
Associate Work - Long Form: Several of the firm's attorneys are associates and are kept busy.
Office Space - Long Form: Lease cost is $30-35k/month.  Currently, they are negotiating with their landlord for a reduced lease fee.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 5/28:

Daniel Lula is a litigation partner in Baker Hostetler's Orange County offices.  His practice involves employment and commercial litigation.  He went to Harvard Law and Stanford undergrad and joined Dewey Leboeuf, where he was mentored as a young associate by Paul Gupta.  Daniel is a New Englander and started his career in Boston but moved to California to join a litigation boutique.   He stayed for 15 years and made partner, and then went to Baker Hostetler to be part of a larger firm.   He now wants to return to the Boston area and is tired of BigLaw micromanagement.  He read Rimon's White Paper and remembered Paul and thinks Rimon would be a perfect fit for him. 

Daniel has longstanding clients (including Peraton, Inc. and the United Methodist Church) which makes up over 50% of his book ($1.3mm last year, on pace for the same this year).  The other 50% is one-off litigation matters which he said "always come."  Daniel wants to keep his CA practice and begin to build a East Coast practice (he has hired a marketing professional to help him do this).

He does not need an office other than for collaboration and the use of a conference room on occasion.  He utilizes 300-500 hours of associate time/year, particularly when he goes to trial (he has a trial set in September).  He would like to have a partner or associate to help him with his trials, and he also would want to try cases with a paralegal (he uses paralegal time sporadically).

Daniel appears to be very bright, driven and entrepreneurial.  I think he would make a fine addition to Rimon.

His clients include start-ups, midsize M&A deals and Chinese companies seeking to do business in the US. In 2021, Julian moved with another partner from Pillsbury to Venable but that move did not work because he needed a stronger international platform.  He moved to his current firm (Procopio) in 2022.  The firm has not helped him grow his practice and want him to have a book over $1mm despite the lack of help.  He needs lawyers who do CIFIUS, life sciences IP and international tax and his current firm does not have this expertise.  Rimon does.

Last year, Julian's book was $800k (his worst year in several).  He is on pace for $900k this year.  Rate is $800.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 6/28:

Tim is a funds partner (hedge funds, fund managers, GPSs) who also has a blockchain, AI, crypto practice.  He is also an English solicitor who handles UK law for some clients.  His book is routinely at or over $5mm and his rate when he left Dechert was $1,650.

He spent several years at Dechert and made a move to McDermott.  Unfortunately for him, the McDermott move did not work out as there apparently was a conflict that fouled the move even after Tim made it.  He is now on his own since May and deciding amongst several firms as to his next steps.  He did not explain this situation in any detail to me and said he would do so if he decided to proceed with Rimon.

As for Rimon, Tim wanted to expand his search beyond traditional firms.  He understood and appreciated Rimon's model but is still speaking with several firms and will have to decide what he wants to do.

He does sometimes invest in his startup clients.

He has been fully remote for the last four years so does not need an office.  

Tim's practice is leveraged.  1/3 of the value of his book is his time (and 100% of his AI and blockchain practice is his time), the other 2/3 is other partners (ERISA, tax, blue sky filings) and associates.  He was unsure as to how much associate time he uses, but I suspect he would need an associate for himself.

Tim could be an excellent addition to Rimon but I'm unsure as to how serious he was about joining us.

What about Rimon is Particularly Excitin: Ability to work remotely;Brand;Collaboration model;International/Regional capabilities
Interest in Rimon - Long Form:
(1) To maximize business development by moving to a firm with a national footprint and much broader expertise across practice areas. I feel that being at a DFW only firm has capped my potential. 
(2) To partner and learn from partners who have truly first-rate expertise/credentials. My current firm operates too much as a collection of partners who operate within their own silos. 
(3) I am impressed by Rimon’s unique, innovative, thoughtful approach to practicing law and believe the firm would offer more flexibility, efficiency, and overall fulfillment in my practice. The flexibility would also help me practice from Salt Lake for stretches, which has become important given my father’s recent diagnosis with late stage lung cancer.
Cross-Service -Long Form: Joseph could not quantify exact numbers he cross-sells to other practice groups but estimates at least $150k-200k.
Admin Support -Long Form: Joseph is somewhat self-sufficient but does need some paralegal support. He would like to know how trial support is handled.
Office Space - Long Form: May need a conference room during trial prep.
Other Needs - Long Form: Joseph would like to know how trial support is handled. Joseph met with Jennifer Smiley and Jennifer Wood for a legal support assessment and they are satisfied that his practice can be supported when he initially joins. SEE NOTES for additional information.
Rimon Initial Interview:
Joseph Callister is a litigation partner in the Dallas office of Wick Phillips where his practice focuses on business and commercial litigation. Joseph has practiced at his current firm since 2011- ten years as a partner and has experience in most areas of litigation. Prior to joining his current firm, he was an associate with Gibson Dunn.

Joseph is looking for a firm with a national footprint, name recognition and a hybrid platform. He believes this would enable him to offer his clients a broader range of services while having more flexibility and autonomy. 

Joseph's clients are spread across multiple industries and range from high-net-worth individuals to large, publicly traded companies such as Match.com (which has been his client for 10 years). Joseph’s current firm is a regional, mid-market firm and he feels that there is a "ceiling" on the types of client matters he can bring to the firm. Moving to a national firm with more resources would open up additional opportunities that he is currently leaving on the table.

Joseph annually originates between $750k and $1mm and his hourly rates range between $600-$650/hr. He rarely does contingency work but when he has, he has used a hybrid model with good success. He would be interested in learning how Rimon litigation attorneys are supported during trial. Outside of his litigation work, he regularly originates corporate, real estate and bankruptcy work which he would love to refer within the same firm. 

Joseph would like to make a move over the summer (before school starts back up). He is speaking with 4 other firms but believes Rimon is the best overall fit for him. He is very easy-going and entrepreneurial and would make a good addition to the firm and litigation team.
Porting Personnel Notes: None at this time.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Loren has been a partner in the Salt Lake City office of Holland & Hart for 6 years (since 2018). Before joining Holand & Hart, Loren was a partner at Stoel Rives, where he practiced 11 years and served as the co-leader of the firm’s Life Sciences practice group. Loren also spent two years in-house as IP counsel.

Loren has a thriving practice which is almost completely patent prosecution (U.S. and foreign). An important part of his client service is strategic counseling and advice. Loren has a solid client base with portables over $1mm. Most of his clients are in the life sciences area, though there are some that fall outside that realm such as medical devices, pharmaceuticals, biotechnology, and a few outliers within the strict chemical space.  A recent area of growth in his practice has been industrial designs, particularly work on consumer products, and he hopes to continue growing that particular area of his practice with his move.

The life sciences group at Holland & Hart used to be one of the largest practice groups within their firm but changes in the firm's direction have left Loren in a tiny subgroup and under-resourced. His firm is now focused on growing the computer science group which has also resulted in a diminished level of collaboration and cross-selling opportunities which were previously good.  

Loren has hourly billing arrangements for all his clients (current rack rate is $830/hr.) He is hoping to gain more control over his rates and use AFAs for specific international clients who are rate sensitive. Loren would plan to bring at least one associate, an IP specialist and a paralegal to support his practice.

Loren is a great fit from a practice, business and cultural aspect and would also give us expanded capabilities and cross-selling opportunities within the life sciences arena.
Porting Personnel Notes: 1 associate, 1 IP Specialist, 1 paralegal at minimum.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Started own practice about 2 years ago; is a divorced father with a pre-school daughter and solo practice is too isolating, all-consuming, and difficult to grow (and to realize $$ on referrals out) so is looking to join a firm; walked me through his work history on concern about frequent moves - was at first firm 5 years and made partner but had collectible issue arise that he felt firm did not do right by him and he did not want to stay; went to an accounting firm next and liked it, but couldn't realize (or get paid for) growing his practice and that restricted business growth; then to Culhane where he got less than $5K in work from other attnys despite promises of much more; left for last firm which was salaried with lots of billable hour pressure, was on track for $600K there, but didn't like the top down mgmt pressure and lack of autonomy, so started his own firm

practice is primarily international tax (65%) with clients in lots of different countries, but most work comes from Western Europe, India, and South America, with a few others from Australia and other countries; clients are typically smaller matters with only occasional repeat business (no one client makes up more than 5% of his client base); current book is $450-600K, typical billable rate is $625/hr with possibility of raising it; he can live on Rimon compensation model at that level to start with, but is motivated to build practice; does have (inactive) FL bar license and would be open to activating that and doing both tax and T&E work in FL; also excited about Rimon's international footprint and specifically about Central/South America and UK as areas he would want to partner with Rimon lawyers who need international tax help; could probably use a few hours of help from a tax associate if that was available. Rimon Initial Interview:
Tom is a seasoned trust and estates partner at Dinsmore & Schohl's Columbus, OH office and has been practicing since 1975. Tom focuses his practice on estate planning, trust and probate estate administration and litigation. He advises professional and individual trustees on administration and fiduciary litigation matters, and his clients include executors, administrators and heirs in probate estates, trusts and guardianships. He has a broad practice, with clients that are high net worth individuals who require sophisticated drafting and advice, as well as more traditional and straight-forward wills/trusts drafting. His litigation clients are primarily closely held businesses.  Tom is a former member of his firm’s Board of Directors and Executive Committee. Tom is also an experienced arbitrator and mediator.
 
Tom is a rainmaker and generates revenue and manages the workload for himself and others in the firm. The bulk of his clients come through referrals, and he has a steady flow of business. He has orginated over $2mm in is current practice, however he estimates about $1.0- 1.2mm would port with him if he were to move. His current rates are $870/hr for T&E work, $450/hr for arbitration (although, he would raise those to $550-650/hr). His expert witness fees are $600-800. He regularly refers litigation and M&A work.

Tom feels that he is being unfairly compensated for the business he is originating, and changes in management have put restrictions upon him as a senior partner. Tom was delightful to speak with and is looking for a firm where he can continue to practice, generate business and collaborate with other attorneys. If Tom is able to bring an associate with him, he would be a nice addition to the firm.

Her hourly rates were $450-600 (averaging over $500).

In June 2022, Kari left LB because both her mother and son were ill and she said one of her partners had asked her to do something unethical.  The medical issues have resolved and Kari is eager to rejoin a firm.  

Kari was very confident that her clients will come back to her - she said that they have been very loyal and are constantly calling her and asking when she will return.  She can't guarantee the amount of business she will generate in her first 12 months, but seemed confident it would be well over $500,000 (she said she very much enjoys marketing her practice). Thereafter, she strongly believes her book will go back over $1M.

Kari is a bit of a risk since she has not been in a firm for the past year.  But the reason she left her firm makes perfect sense and I strongly believe she will be successful.  I recommend we proceed with her candidacy.

Title: Partner
Rimon Initial Interview:
Robert (“Rob”) Pepple is a partner in the Labor & Employment practice group in Nixon Peabody’s Los Angeles office where he has practiced the last 2 ½ years. He represents large, medium, and small employers (from Fortune 500 companies to mom-and-pop businesses) in a wide array of labor and employment matters, including litigation, alternative dispute resolution, and day-to-day advice and counsel. He has extensive experience defending high-stakes wage and hour class actions, derivative Private Attorney Generals Act lawsuits, and a variety of single-plaintiff employment matters.

Rob started his law career as an associate at Paul Hastings in 2013 and moved with a group of labor and employment lawyers to Venable, then to Epstein Becker and finally Nixon Peabody.  In his practice, Rob works closely with a 6th year associate, Alejandro Castro, who would transition with him. The majority of their work is wage and hour compliance. Together they bring a combined portable book of business of about $2.5mm with several clients that pay $20k flat fees per month. Rob's hourly rates range from $650-$1,000/hour depending on the type of matter and client. 

Rob defines his practice as less litigation and more quantifiable analysis. He has developed a system of analytics, checklists, budgets, calculators and workflow processes that help him “diagnose” his clients’ issues with efficiency and accuracy. He is then able to develop the appropriate strategies which often result in mediation and average approximately $200k-$250k per mediation. More complex cases can scale up to $1mm if the proceed to litigation.

Rob’s primary frustration with his current firm comes from continuing to originate clients but not seeing the full credit or revenue because he is not yet an equity partner.  Ongoing rate pressure adds to this frustration. Rob is impressed with Rimon's internal market collaboration and very interested in cross-selling and referral opportunities. If conversations progress favorably, there is a possibility that Rob may be able to convince an additional partner (commercial litigation) to make the move as well. 

Rob is very high energy, neurodivergent and very smart. He also has interest and experience in law firm pro bono and DEI. His practice appears to be a good fit for Rimôn and if the numbers bear out, we should continue the conversation.
Secondary Practice Group: 85% wage and hour advice and litigation; 15% employment advice and counsel, trade secrets, general litigation, reasoning through business problems, etc.
Porting Personnel Notes: possibly - A 6th-year Associate, Alejandro Castro ($250k) would port with Rob. There is a good possibility that Richard Frey, a labor and employment/commercial litigation partner (not presented by the search firm) may also make the move. Two more labor & employment partners (not presented by the search firm) may be interested at a later date.

 He is confident that all of his patent prosecution work for HOYA ($700-800k) will follow him and there is also a trademark matter which may be worth $400k in fees that he would want to pitch for.  Any new litigations would also come to him.

James loves to cross sell.  In his first year at his current firm, he won the firm's "collaboration award." Cross selling includes corporate, advertising, L&E and is in addition to his stated book. 

He does not need an office and does not currently need associate help (he would if he had active litigation).  Core support needed would be a docketing clerk that he would consider sponsoring. 

James is a top Rimon candidate.  I would highly recommend continuing the process.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Ed 3/29:

Sohan is a fantastic Rimon candidate.  Friendly, hungry, entreprenurial.  He is a litigator with a focus on international arbitration and white collar matters, but he also does commercial litigaiton as well.

Sohan had a career before the law and obtained a PhD. in international law before he graduated from law school in '16. Upon graduation, Sohan entered government service, where he served as Deputy General Counsel of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and as Special Counsel of the U.S. Department of Education (ED).  Thereafter, he joined a small firm (Shaerr Jaffe) where he had several friends.  The problem is that the firm only did political work and Sohan wanted to expand into commercial and white-collar work and wanted to join a larger firm.  So after one year at Shaerr, he joined Frost Brown Todd as a nonequity partner.  Weeks later Taft made him an equity partner offer that he was counseled by many colleagues not to refuse.

He was not looking to move when he received a call from the recruiter.  Because of our international reach and our compensation model Rimon was very interesting to him which is why he agreed to speak with us. 

In a short amount of time, Sohan has built a $1mm+ portable practice at Taft (current rates are $700-875/hour). Clients include governments, financial institutions and corporations in several industries.  He also has generated another $250-300k in cross selling, including tax, corporate (transnational agreements) and real estate.  He does not need office space (although he could use our N.Va. offices) .  He uses paralegal time to format briefs and for proofreading, and he gives maybe 400 hours/year to associates, so he is largely self-sufficient.

As he was not looking to leave his current firm, and because he is early in his legal career, Sohan wants some time to consider whether now is the right time to join Rimon.  I hope he decides it is.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Pamela Kearse is a partner in the Business & Finance group of Chicago-based Horwood Marcus & Berk (HMB Legal Counsel) working remotely from D.C. and Atlanta. Before joining HMB, Pamela was Managing Chief Counsel and Asst. Corporate Secretary of the Corporate Governance and Transactions Groups at McKesson. 

Pamela's practice is focused on advising privately held companies and investors on complex commercial transactions, securities compliance issues, data privacy issues, and other corporate governance issues. About 50% of her practice is M&A with the rest being outside GC advice, securities compliance including periodic reporting, Sec. 16 filings for corporate executives, proxy statement filings, ESG guidance, responding to shareholder proposals and inquiries, and commercial contracts. Pamela regularly works with other practice groups and refers work in corporate tax, executive compensation and ERISA, tax and AI expertise. Pamela is the origination partner for all but two of her clients.

Pamela's reasons for exploring other opportunities include: HMB is merging with Kilpatrick Stockton and requires that she relocate to Chicago away from family; she has experienced institutional conflicts with bringing over McKesson as a client to HMB; she has had to turn away work due to the deal size, and Kilpatrick is not focused on M&A growth. 

Pamela appears confident and collaborative and is very interested in Rimon's model and the opportunity for more autonomy with her clients. If her business plan projections are realized, she would be a great addition to the firm.
Secondary Practice Group: General Corporate - 25%, Corporate Governance - 25%, M&A - 20%, SEC Disclosure and Compliance - 20%, Corporate Finance - 10%
Porting Personnel Notes: None at this time. Will reassess whether to bring her paralegal after 6 months at the firm.

Rimon Initial Interview:
Holly Gilani is currently a partner at Hess-Verdon, a trust and estates boutique firm in Newport Beach, CA, where she has practiced almost 20 years and is the head of the Trust & Estates Practice Group.

Holly has a thriving practice advising high-net-worth individuals, family-owned conglomerates, and corporate executives on trust law, estate tax, breach of fiduciary duty and corporate matters and has experience in trust litigation representing trustees and beneficiaries. 

One of her largest cases involved over $200mm worth of assets, 12 partnerships and a corporation. She has consistently generated between $700k to $1mm a year and her current billing rate is $750/hour. Over the last 3 years, Holly’s practice has focused on trust and estates litigation. Holly has previously run her own firm and considers herself a trusted advisor and strategist. She has become an outside GC to many of her loyal clients and already has commitments from several clients to follow her and send more work her way. 

Holly likes the global reach of Rimon and the hybrid platform. Holly has other potential clients that she has not been able to bring in because of the limited reach of her current firm. She has many regional and U.S. clients, but also has an extensive global network in the Middle East, India, and Dubai (she previously lived and worked as a legal consultant in Dubai). She believes a move to Rimon would open up additional opportunities to grow her business. 

At her current firm, attorneys are highly encouraged to work on institutional clients rather than originate their own. Holly would like to continue building her business and is looking for a firm more focused on innovation and collaboration. She was very excited about our model and is confident that she could add value. Holly typically refers securities, tax and family law matters. Holly is admitted to practice in California and D.C.

Holly is extremely confident, personable and has a great track record. She also enjoys mentoring associates. She would be a good addition for the T&E group and the firm.
