Rimon Initial Interview:
Brian is a pleasant, loquacious and very confident corporate partner, who often acts as outside GC to his clients. He has special expertise in crypto.  He also has a strong disputes resolutions background and does handle some litigation matters.

Brian describes himself as a rainmaker who develops business across multiple practice areas (litigation, crypto, privacy, real estate, sports/entertainment, etc.).  His book this year is $2mm but he would have to consider how much of that work would follow him as many of his partners are actively engaged on several matters.  Brian is confident at least half of his book would follow and that he could quickly ramp up from there.

Brian spent 10 years at Jones Day (doing litigation and arbitrations along with corporate matters) before joining Loeb & Loeb.  From there, in 2013, Brian launched a crypto/financial services company and then in 2020 launched his own outsource consulting/general counsel firm (where he said he made more money in his first year than he ever did at a law firm).  He joined his current firm in '21 when one of his partners who was working on one of Brian's client's matters suggested it on the golf course.  

Brian likes the people at Lowenstein but he thinks they might not be the right fit for him.  He does not think the firm has a long enough reach or a deep enough bench across multiple practice areas.  Brian considers himself to be a "hub," constantly networking and generating business that he hands off to other partners and there is not enough cross selling.

Brian cannot personally handle all of the work that he brings in.  He originates work (IP, employment, tax (private wealth), bankruptcy, disputes, etc.) and hands that work to his partners who do use associates.  Brian himself does not occupy the time of a single associate or paralegal although many associates and paras bill time to his matters through the working partners.  He has one current FINRA matter on which a paralegal is billing "hundreds" of hours.

Brian also has a putative contingency fee case involving market manipulation by banks that he would be interested in exploring if he were to join Rimon.  He said that case could "dwarf" his other matters and he would like to discuss logistics of this potential case, including litigation financing, reduced hourly rates with a success fee, etc.

He needs no office (although he would go into the Long Island office periodically and sometimes meet clients in Manhattan).  He also does not need a legal assistant and describes himself as tech savvy.

Current rate $1,290.

As I said above, Brian is very confident and very talkative.  But I liked him and I think he might be a good fit for Rimon.

Rimon Initial Interview: Pat is from Long Island; has 6 kids and is a St John's basketball fan; moved from Jones Day to in-house because there was no path to partnership for him at JD and mentor suggested move to client, but Pat always wanted to return to private practie and build a practice at a firm; got lots of RE compliance, regulatory, and even dome leasing/development exposure at his in-house position, in addition to managing lots of litigation; no upward mobility at his company and GC recommended he go to Duane Morris as that was a firm that the co used; he has built practice to $1.3M in originations in first year, but frustrated with overhead, bureaucracy, origination credit, and lack of rate flexibility; his practice is about $300K for former in-house company, but the rest comes from business referrals and contacts he has made over his career; wants to be able to take matters and cases for wide range of clients from start-ups through public companies; explained comp models and he quickly got it and asked good questions; very intriqued by lower overhead, distributed model, but doesn;t want to  be siloed; does majority of early case work himself, but if case goes to discovery , motions, trial, then works with 1 other P. occasionally 1-2 associates, and maybe a paralegal; occasionally has e-discovery needs, but not that often; currently has 2 active cases that he would like to take to his new firm; ideal timing would be in early April after Duane Morris does their comp distributions for 2024 in March; agreed he would like to talk with other Rimon Ps and also JZ; seemed sharp, energetic, and comfortable with our model and use of technology; think he would be a really good fit with our LI and/or NYC office

Title: Partner
Rimon Initial Interview: represents Miami Dolphins and Hard Rock stadium in liability matters and now has a conflict at his current firm; has experience doing a variety of types of business litigation, but gets a majority of his work now from firm referrals; think he could build his sports-related litigation practice if he was at another firm (to Orlando, Jax and Tampa teams), but would need  assurances of lit work from others to make it work financially; might have $300K in portables; does not come across as polished or really driven; combination of low portables and poor impression leads me to recommend we pass
Secondary Practice Group: mainly Defense clients within entertainment & sports.

Title: Partner
Rimon Initial Interview: Howard lives in NJ, 2 children, son 16 and daughter 13; mother lives in China; worked for Bristol Myers after US grad school doing research, then decided to go to law school; worked for firm form 2005-2019 when firm had some financial issues and them left with his group for current firm that is an ANDA lit boutique; about 6-7 years ago, staritng developing own client base that began with Indian generic pharma clients and has expanded to include Chinese generic pharma clients; 85-90% of his practice is Hatch-Waxman litigation; currently has 2 ongoing litigation cases for Chinese cos as well as multiple other consultation and opinion work; he can do most of the work at the beginning of a case by himself, then as case progresses, he generally looks for more senior lit support from lawyers with trial experience and some associate support; bills hourly for almost all work, with some fixed fee for small transactional matters (in range of $5K); looking to move to have flexibility with rates and billing, to avoid conflicts he is having at current firm (with co-defendants); legal support needs include Lexis/Westlaw, a couple of Hatch-Waxman specific subscriptions; uses outside vendor for e-discovery and for trial presentation; travels to China 1-2x/yr for client development and conferences; asked about marketing support, conflicts issues with Big Pharma, and if he could use Princeton office as his drop box/mailing address b/c of companies doing business there; ideally he owuld like to make a move in late Fe/early March, but does have one trial currently set for end of March and may need to stay at current firm if that does not settle until that trial is over; seemed genuinely interested and asked thoughtful questions; will send him info on firm tiers and work with Jen Liu and Juan to get list of Rimon Ps for him to interview with (as well as to meet with Juan)
Secondary Practice Group: ADNA litigation, Patent Hatch-Waxman litigation 85%; Work related to pharmaceutical, medical device and chemical fields

Title: Partner
Rimon Initial Interview: call with JZ and CJ; Rodrigo took the lead in the conversation, but it appears that Jorge has a more substantial practice (and larger book); Jorge does trade litigation work throughout Mexico and has a team that does $3-4M/yr, about $1M of which is his own collections; Rodrigo described his practice as more in teh $1.5M range, but said he depends on firm clients for a good bit of his work; Jorge was passed over for equity partner and was unhappy with the lack of transparency and the overhead costs at Baker; after going through economic model, they had questions about transition assistance/guarantees and amount of work they could bring; will send them modeling spreadsheet; Rodrigo did volunteer that they do not have to leave together and one or the other would move separately if it made sense; did not get a very positive vibe and think Rimon may be too risky for them
Porting Personnel Notes: there may be an opportunity for other attorneys to join them

Title: Partner
Closing reason details: from Debra S. rcr:" He’s close to a few offers on traditional platforms and seems to want to stay on the traditional side for now"
Secondary Practice Group: Civil Litigation, Guardianship and Competency Proceedings, Civil Sexual Abuse Claims Defense
Porting Personnel Notes: Wants to bring his son as an associate (he will be taking the bar later this year) He will also bring an outstanding support partner with him and possibly another associate.

Title: Managing Partner
Sector/Practice: Cannabis Law;Construction;Commercial Litigation;Government Contracts;White Collar Crime
Rimon Initial Interview: Henry is from Minnesota, wife is from South of France and after a few years in Chicago after law school, moved to Denver; was with Armstrong Teasdale, then to this boutique; he and 1 other P are the lit group - his own portable book fluctuates from 1.2-2.6M with an average of 1.5M; firm's lease is up in a year and they need to decide what to do in advance of that; he wants to maintain his competitive advantage on rates (so doesn't want to join BigLaw), but also wants to capture referral work out, which includes tax and real estate work; they also are looking to solve succession issues as main business developers will likely cut back or retire in 5-7 years and they don't think they have the associates to take over those practices; in addition to litigation practice, 1 partner has transactional/corp practice (Julie) and 1 has employment practice (Chris); current firm comp structure is similar to Rimon; asked lots of Qs about financial model, taxes, etc; said move could be just the litigation team (2Ps, 1-2 As) or most of the 8 lawyers; has typical needs for legal research, doc mgmt; asked if we had e-discovery software; uses vendors for most of his trial presentation needs; has partner meeting on 11/25; sending him modeling spreadsheet, benefits info, support info for that; he will connect after that meeting and if interest, likely want to talk with a Rimon P who has brought a group over; liked his attitude, forward-thinking, but pragmatic, thorough, pleasant, didn't seem to have an attitude/big ego and seemed like he would like to jettison some of the responsibilities of being a managing partner
Secondary Practice Group: Firm's Practices include: Commercial Litigation, Corporate / Securities / M&A; Employment Law; Tax; Cannabis; Trademark; Construction; Trusts & Estates; Psychedelics; Compliance Programs and Internal Investigations; and Real Estate
Porting Personnel Notes: Heny and a few other attorneys can port without the remainder of the firm. likely, at most, ten total attorneys will port

Title: Partner
Sector/Practice: Intellectual Property Litigation;Litigation;Sports, Entertainment, and Recreation
Closing Reason: Chose to stay at current firm
Closing reason details: see notes
Rimon Initial Interview: Jim's practice is all TM and patent litigation; started at Kirkland, then Skadden, then Quinn Emanuel, now at Fox Rothschild; he is 71 yo and firm has mandatory retirement from equity P-ship at 72 (for him next Jan);  thinking about making a move to a firm where he can transition his practice to bill less and originate more; current rate is $1400/hr, but he discounts that to closer to $1000; currently making $600K/yr in comp; last couple of years has collected $1.5M on his own time for his clients, but has generated approx $3M in revenue total; avgs $100-125K/month in collections on his time with one client paying him a $50K retainer so he would not likely need any transition assistance; would need a team to work on his client matters - partner(s), associate, some paralegal with experience in TM and patent cases; also asked about some minimal level of admin assistance for court filings; ideally he would move his rate back to $700/800 hr and over next 3-5 years transition his clients to younger P/team; other consideration is that he has is a $500K pension that he would forfeit if he left Fox; very straightforward, non-nonsense type; got right to the point and asked good Qs about our model and comp system; we will need to get a better sense of his tech savviness and ability to function in a remote environment; he wanted to do some calculations and will call me early next week to see if he wants to proceed; if we can provide a team that can work with him and his clients and we/he are comfortable on the tech side, this could be a good succession planning type addition

Title: Managing Partner
Mailing City: Emirates, Kuwait, Egypt, and Saudi Arabia
Private Frederick/Mgmt Notes: Will need 3 assistants (1 in each office) at approx $24k salary each. Can do client intake and billing. MBM offered them a scaled model: 70% for first $1mil, then something like 75% for next mil, then 80% for third mil. Office would be reimbursed after first mil.
Private Management Notes:
Offices: would joint venture with local firms that would let us use their offices.

From Alex 12/09/19: P&L's

https://rimon1-my.sharepoint.com/:w:/g/personal/susan_moy_rimonlaw_com/EfphjNN6HddJt9eQxkahoBUB7iZv9l5OBXw8XmRxvOdY6g?e=QEqbKC

With respect to our last call, I have prepared and attached a starting point for discussions with respect to financials.  We made the following assumptions with respect to projections:

1.  Our current book is about US$ 5 Million.  We assume that in our first year leaving our firm, it would drop to US1 Million, second year $2 Million and third year $3 Million.  It is very simplistic, but probably relatively accurate.

2.  Our rental expenses would be kept a minimum because we will try to sublease from our JV partners in the three jurisdictions.

3.  We wish to keep the associate count low to be in harmony with the overall hybrid cloud based philosophy of Rimon.

4.  One of our partners is out, so we have the three remaining partners, Philip, Aaron, and myself.

5.  With respect to the Rimon fees, we were proposing a lower fee of 10%, but increasing to 15% the second year and 17.5 the third year.  This should result in cash flow to Rimon of over $40,000 per month by said time.
Tell us a little about your clients: Represents a lot of the Kuwaiti banks and oil companies
Closing reason details: converted as per MBM

Title: CEO
Closing Reason: Chose to stay at current firm
Private Management Notes:
MBM (11/30/22):  Jen was the COO of WeWork. That can be a good thing or a bad thing. It is good since it was an extremely high-level position of a multi-billion-dollar company. It is bad since the company famously imploded. Overall, I think it would bring experience to our firm that we do not have (in-house real estate experience) and some PR. Before WeWork, she was a partner at Wilmer Hale (a very elite law firm) with a book of business of $4mil. I think she made good money at WeWork, but I don't know. She was probably a billionaire on paper for a while.
 
Now she is working on an AI-driven legal tech concept, starting with NDAs.
Closing reason details: converted as per MBM

Title: Partner
Closing reason details: Rimon isn't the right fit at the moment
Rimon Initial Interview: Rich worked as a mechanical engineer for a couple of years before going to law school; graduated in 2009 at height of recession and got job with IP firm Knobbe Martens, there he was doing patent lit and working on a German litigation case (he speaks German); moved to San Diego and joined Kilpatrick and moved into patent prosecution work, where he developed an expertise doing software control of mechanical devices in the medical device industry; also has an expertise in AI patenting in both the US and Europe; has children and moved to Park City Utah a few years ago and works remotely; clients come from relationships he has developed with In-house lawyers and has one that can start sendign him significant work (at least $1M/yr), but there is a conflict at KT with that client so he is looking to leave; would ideally like to move by himself, get his practice up and running and then look at brining other lawyers with him (likely an associate or two to start); has standard patent pros needs for docketing and PTO fees, but not a super high volume practice; does a lot of opinion work also for Abbott and Illumina, opining on patents owned by J&J, Boston Scientific; Hatch-Waxman representation of generic pharma would not be an issue for his clients as he is not int he pharma area, but the med device area and in his experience, waivers are pretty standard if outside of med device technology; wanted to explore more the practical aspects of running an IP practice at Rimon and agreed to talk with 1 or 2 partners; he was close to accepting an offer with a firm last week, but then a conflict issue arose and he backed away from that firm; wants to move sooner rather than later to start the representation of the large client he can't work for at KT; he comes across as very friendly and communicates easily and well, especially for a patent pros lawyer; doesn't appear to have an ego and said he works well in teams;  good sense of humor - think he would be an excellent fit and we should do all we can to have him seriously consider Rimon
